vignette.presentation:
4. A 10-year-old girl is brought to the office by her parents because of a 3-year history of impulsive and inattentive behavior. Her parents had been trying to manage her behavior at home and
school, but during the past 6 months, she has had a marked decline in functioning at school and extracurricular activities. She has been in trouble for being disruptive and not following
instructions. She has no history of serious illness and receives no medications. Growth and development are appropriate for age. Physical and mental status examinations show no
abnormalities. Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk for which of the following?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) presents with chronic symptoms of hyperactivity/impulsivity and/or inattention that occur in more than one setting and impair academic, social, and/or
emotional function. Children with predominant hyperactivity symptoms are unable to sit still and may have difficulty taking turns (postulated to result from a dysregulated dopamine reward pathway),
whereas children with predominant inattentive symptoms tend to daydream, process information slowly, and demonstrate difficulty in completing tasks (related to norepinephrine dysregulation).
Difficulty with impulse control commonly leads to emotional dysregulation. There is an increased rate of substance use disorders in children and adults with ADHD compared to those without the
condition. Researchers have theorized that individuals with ADHD may self-medicate with substances to help regulate their emotions or improve attention. Stimulants, which include amphetamine
salts and methylphenidate, are first-line agents that increase synaptic dopamine and norepinephrine.
explanation.educational_objective:
Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) presents with chronic symptoms of hyperactivity/impulsivity and/or inattention that occur in more than one setting and impair
academic, social, and/or emotional function. Possibly a result of difficulty with emotion regulation, patients with ADHD are more likely than the general population to develop substance use disorders.

vignette.presentation:
5. An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because he has had the rash shown for 1 week; the rash began as a small 1-cm lesion on his cheek. His younger brother has had a similar
rash for 5 days. The patient had an upper respiratory tract infection 8 days ago treated with an over-the-counter decongestant. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F). Which of the following is the most likely
explanation for these findings?

© B) Bacteria infection

€} Fungal infection

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Bacterial infection, in this case impetigo, is a contagious, superficial skin infection often caused by Staphylococcus aureus. Impetigo is common among young children but also occurs in adults. Impetigo is
often localized to sites where there is breakdown of the normal skin barrier, such as in conditions like atopic dermatitis. Impetigo may begin as superficial vesicles or pustules that spread locally. Rupture of
these vesicles and pustules leads to development of erosions with overlying, adherent, honey-colored crusting. Systemic involvement is uncommon in patients with impetigo. Bacterial culture and sensitivity
testing may be obtained to further determine the causative pathogen and to guide antibiotic therapy. Topical antibiotics, including mupirocin, are often sufficient for the treatment of impetigo. In severe cases of
impetigo, oral antibiotics such as cephalexin or clindamycin may be used.
explanation.educational_objective:
Impetigo is a contagious, superficial bacterial infection often caused by Staphylococcus aureus and is common in children. Impetigo begins as focal superficial vesicles or pustules that
spread locally and rupture, leaving behind an erythematous base with an overlying honey-colored crust. Impetigo is diagnosed clinically, but bacterial culture can be performed to identify the specific pathogen.
Topical antibiotics such as mupirocin are the mainstay of treatment in localized cases. Systemic antibiotics are reserved for severe cases.

vignette.presentation:
6. A 16-year-old girl comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Menarche was at the age of 12 years. Menses occur
at irregular 28- to 34-day intervals with light flow; her last menstrual period was 10 weeks ago. She participates in after-school sports, including soccer and track, and receives grades of A's and B's. She
appears well groomed, affable, and engages readily in discussion. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 51 kg (112 Ib); BMI is 18 kg/m2, Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood
pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Sexual maturity rating is stage 4 for breast and pubic hair development. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A} Measurement of serum-freetestosterone concentration
B} Pelvie-tltresenegraphy

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Secondary amenorrhea may be caused by pregnancy, menopause or premature ovarian failure, ovulatory dysfunction, abnormalities of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis, inadequate nutrition, chromosomal
abnormalities, and thyroid disorders. In patients with secondary amenorrhea, a careful history should be taken, including the patient's menstrual history, sexual activity, contraceptive usage, and the possibility of
pregnancy. Light vaginal bleeding can also ocour early in pregnancy, often as a result of implantation of the embryo, which can occasionally be mistaken for menses, so the provider should maintain a low index
of suspicion for pregnancy in the setting of amenorrhea. Other symptoms of early pregnancy include fatigue, nausea, breast tenderness, and fatigue. Physical examination may show an enlarged, globular uterus,
but a formal diagnosis is made with urine or serum pregnancy testing that measures B-hCG, which would be the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient. B-hCG is produced by the placenta,
undetectable in nonpregnant patients, and doubles approximately every 48 hours during early pregnancy. In an uncomplicated pregnancy, an intrauterine gestational sac should be visible by 5 weeks’ gestation.
explanation.educational_objective:
Secondary amenorrhea can have a variety of causes. A thorough history and physical examination should be performed to help determine the underlying cause. A serum or urine
pregnancy test should always be the first test in evaluating amenorrhea as failure to identify a pregnancy increases the risk for peripartum complications.

vignette.presentation:
7. A19-year-old college student is brought to the emergency department by her roommates because of increasing confusion during the past 24 hours. She also has had decreased appetite for 2 days. On arrival, she is difficult to arouse. Her temperature
is 38.9°C (102°F), and respirations are 28/min and deep. Her pulse is 124/min, and blood pressure is 80/42 mm Hg while sitting; her pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 110/50 mm Hg while supine. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Abdominal
‘examination shows mild diffuse tendemess to palpation. Serum studies show:
Na* 130 mEq/L
Kr 5.2 mEq/L
cr 98 mEq/L
HCO." 7 mEq
Glucose 700 mg/dL.
Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:
pH 7.16
Pco,  20mmHg
Pop 108 mm Hg
This patient most likely has which of the following primary acid-base disorders?
_ A) Metabolic acidosis

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Results of laboratory studies in this patient show markedly increased serum glucose, decreased serum pH and bicarbonate, and normal oxygenation; these findings are consistent with primary metabolic acidosis due to diabetic ketoacidosis. Diabetic
ketoacidosis is caused by the accumulation of serum ketones such as B-hydroxybutyric acid, acetoacetic acid, and acetone in the setting of deficient insulin signaling. Absent insulin signaling leads to dysregulated fatty acid degradation and ketone synthesis
because of a relative state of starvation. It is common for young patients with undiagnosed type 1 diabetes mellitus to present with ketoacidosis, as in this case. Patients present with reports of fatigue, altered mental status or obtundation, polyuria, shortness of
breath, and diffuse abdominal discomfort. Vital signs may show tachycardia and tachypnea. Kussmaul respirations (rapid and deep) are a classic physical examination finding due to respiratory compensation for the underlying metabolic acidosis. Laboratory
studies typically show increased glucose, ketones, and a high anion gap due to the accumulation of unmeasured anions in serum. Anion gap is calculated as the difference between sodium and the sum of bicarbonate and chloride anions. Treatment is through
replacement of insulin, volume repletion, correction of electrolyte abnormalities, and treatment of any precipitating conditions. While analyzing the biochemical results of arterial blood gas analysis, in cases of a high anion gap acidosis, Winters formula should
be used to determine if respiratory compensation for the acidosis is present, or if a second deficit is also present. Winters formula states that the partial pressure of carbon dioxide should equal 1.5 x [bicarbonate] + 8 +/—

vignette.presentation: TBD

explanation.educational_objective:
Diabetic ketoacidosis is a primary metabolic acidosis and is a common initial presentation in young patients with undiagnosed type 1 diabetes mellitus. Patients present with tachycardia, tachypnea, fatigue, altered mental status or
obtundation, polyuria, shortness of breath, and diffuse abdominal discomfort. Laboratory studies typically show increased glucose concentration, ketones, and a high anion gap due to the accumulation of unmeasured anions in serum.

vignette.presentation:
8. A54-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up examination 12 weeks after undergoing aortic valve replacement. The patient is doing well and has been participating in physical therapy as part of his
recovery. His only current symptom is mild fatigue. Medical history also is remarkable for hypertension. Current medications are warfarin, metoprolol, and lisinopril. He has no known medication allergies. Vital
signs are within normal limits. On cardiac examination, a mechanical valve click is heard. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient has a dental cleaning appointment scheduled
for next week at noon. Which of the following is most appropriate to recommend in preparation for this patient's dental visit?

choices.text: 5-Day course of azithromycin starting the morning of the cleaning
3-Day course of levofloxacin starting 3 days before the cleaning

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Infective endocarditis classically presents with fevers, a new heart murmur, fatigue, and septic embolic phenomena such as Janeway lesions and Osler nodes in patients with risk factors. Endocarditis prophylaxis is
recommended for patients with high-risk cardiac features undergoing procedures that put them at increased risk for the development of bacterial endocarditis. These cardiac features include prosthetic heart valves,
prior infective endocarditis, unrepaired congenital cyanotic heart disease, repaired disease with residual shunts or valvular regurgitation near prosthetic material, repaired congenital defects with a catheter-based
intervention (for the first 6 months after the procedure), and valvular regurgitation in a heart transplant recipient. High-risk procedures include dental procedures with gingival manipulation or perforation of the oral
mucosa, respiratory tract procedures in which the mucosa is violated, procedures on infected soft tissue, and cardiac surgery with prosthetic material. Amoxicillin is the most commonly prescribed antibiotic for
bacterial endocarditis prophylaxis, given as a single dose of 2 g, 30 minutes prior to the procedure.
explanation.educational_objective:
Patients with unrepaired congenital cyanotic heart disease, a prior history of endocarditis, or those with prosthetic valves should receive antibiotic prophylaxis against endocarditis prior to high-
risk procedures. High-risk procedures include dental procedures with gingival manipulation or perforation of the oral mucosa, respiratory tract procedures in which the mucosa is violated, procedures on infected soft
tissue, and cardiac surgery with prosthetic material. The prophylactic treatment of choice is typically amoxicillin, given as a one-time dose prior to the procedure.

9. A62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of progressive shortness of breath with exertion, fever, and chills. Two days ago, he coughed up
a small amount of blood-tinged, thick sputum; otherwise, his cough has been nonproductive. Three years ago, he underwent right kidney transplant for end-stage renal
disease caused by polycystic kidney disease. His medications are prednisone, cyclosporine, sirolimus, and a daily multivitamin. He does not smoke cigarettes. His ay % 4 >,
temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation "ye ©
of 94%. Crackles are heard in the right middle and lower lung fields. Abdominal examination shows a well-healed scar over the right lower quadrant. The remainder of 7. >

performed; biopsy results are shown. Cyclosporine therapy is discontinued. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy? a lip R B ¥ -

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Mucormycosis is a serious, life-threatening infection caused by an invasive fungal organism, such as Mucor or Rhizopus. This often results in aggressive infections of the sinuses, nasal cavity, orbits, or lungs,
primarily in patients with a history of inmunocompromise (eg, a posttransplant patient) or poorly controlled diabetes. Patients often present with an eschar of the affected area but may present with blood-tinged
‘sputum if the lungs are involved. Tissue biopsy will show fungal hyphae, as seen in the image. Given the aggressive nature of these infections, amphotericin B is the pharmacotherapy of choice, and treatment often
involves aggressive surgical debridement of the affected tissues.
explanation.educational_objective:
Mucormycosis is a serious, life-threatening infection caused by an invasive fungal organism, such as Mucor or Rhizopus. The infection commonly presents in a patient with a history of
immunocompromise (eg, being posttransplant) or poorly controlled diabetes. Treatment includes prompt administration of systemic amphotericin B, as well as aggressive surgical debridement of the affected tissues.

vignette.presentation:
41. An 81-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. She has felt well but reports painless bruising on her right arm that she noticed 3 days ago after removing a
bandage from a healing insect bite. She has noticed similar bruising during the past few years with bandage use and after accidental bumping of her arms against hard surfaces. She has hypertension
treated with hydrochlorothiazide-triamterene. She takes no other medications. The patient appears well. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows a 4-cm area of ecchymoses with tearing of the
skin on the right forearm at the site of the previously removed bandage. The remainder of the physical examination discloses no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in
management of this patient's skin findings?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Ecchymosis after minor bumps or removal of a bandage in an 81-year-old patient can be considered a normal finding due to several factors related to the aging process. As people age, the skin becomes thinner and
loses elasticity, making it more susceptible to injury. Additionally, the blood vessels become more fragile and are more likely to break and leak blood into the surrounding tissue, leading to the formation of bruises. In
older adults, decreased blood flow to the skin and underlying tissue can also contribute to slow wound healing, making it more likely for bruises to persist. These are all normal physiologic changes expected with
aging. It is important to note that certain medical conditions such as clotting disorders and bleeding disorders can increase the risk for bruising in older adults. However, in the absence of any other concerning
symptoms or underlying medical conditions, the ecchymosis in this patient can be considered a normal finding related to the aging process. Further evaluation, including a thorough medical history and physical
examination, may be necessary to determine if any underlying medical conditions are contributing to the ecchymosis. In this case, without any clear coagulopathy, no implicated medications, and history and
examination findings that are age- and situation-appropriate, no further testing is indicated. For this reason, reassurance is the most appropriate next step.
explanation.educational_objective:
The normal aging process of the skin is characterized by a decline in collagen and elastin, resulting in thinning, decreased elasticity, and increased susceptibility to injury and bruising. It is
important for physicians to educate patients on normal aging processes to avoid unnecessary stress and costly emergency department or office visits for normal conditions.

vignette.presentation:
12. A58-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of nonproductive cough. He has not had shortness of breath or weight loss. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and
chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). His medications are insulin, metformin, salmeterol, ipratropium, and lisinopril. During the examination, the patient coughs frequently. His temperature is
37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 156/70 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination shows a prolonged expiratory phase; no wheezes are heard. The remainder of the
examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's cough?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Lisinopril belongs to the ACE inhibitor drug class. These medications are responsible for blocking angiotensin-converting enzyme, which stops the conversion of angiotensin | to angiotensin II. This decreased
conversion reduces aldosterone synthesis in the adrenal cortex and ultimately results in decreased sodium retention, decreased vasoconstriction, and lower blood pressure. One of the major adverse effects of ACE
inhibitors is a dry cough. This is caused by the blocking of angiotensin-converting enzyme, which also breaks down bradykinin. The presumed mechanism is multifactorial but involves neurosensitization, release of
neurokinins and substance P, and bronchoconstriction, all of which lead to a dry cough. This cough can present at any time during therapy with lisinopril. For this patient, who has an unremarkable physical
examination, the most likely cause of his cough is an adverse effect of lisinopril therapy.
explanation.educational_objective:
Lisinopril belongs to the ACE inhibitor drug class. ACE inhibitors prevent the conversion of angiotensin | to angiotensin II, which ultimately decreases the synthesis of aldosterone in the adrenal
cortex. This leads to decreased vasoconstriction throughout the body. The most common adverse effect of ACE inhibitors is a persistent dry cough caused by decreased breakdown of bradykinin by angiotensin-
converting enzyme.

vignette.presentation:
15. A62-year-old man comes to the physician 24 hours after a 20-minute episode of weakness of the right side of the face and right upper and lower extremities. His blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg. Cardiac

and neurologic examinations, an ECG, and a CT scan of the head show normal findings. Carotid duplex ultrasonography shows less than 50% stenosis of the proximal left internal carotid artery. Which of

the following interventions will result in the greatest reduction of this patient's risk for a cerebral infarction?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Transient ischemic attack is defined as a transient episode of neurologic dysfunction caused by focal brain, spinal cord, or retinal ischemia without evidence of infarction (ie, neuronal death). An embolic ischemic
stroke involves an event in which a clot breaks off and travels to the brain, occluding blood flow at a cerebral artery. Emboli can come from proximal vessels, such as the internal carotid artery, or from an atrial
thrombus. After a transient ischemic attack, measures for prevention of an ischemic stroke should be enacted. Diagnostic workup includes head imaging studies, cardiac imaging studies, and carotid duplex
ultrasonography to determine a possible embolic (ie, extracranial) source of the clot. If no embolic source is identified, an intracranial atherosclerotic-related thrombosis is the likely cause and aspirin therapy should
be initiated to decrease the risk for future thrombotic events. Aspirin is an antiplatelet agent commonly used in the prophylaxis of arterial thrombotic phenomena involving the cerebral arteries (eg, cerebrovascular
accidents).
explanation.educational_objective:
After a transient ischemic attack, management should be enacted to prevent a future thromboembolic event. Patients without an identifiable embolic source should initiate aspirin therapy to
decrease the risk for future intracranial thrombus formation. Aspirin is an antiplatelet agent commonly used in the prophylaxis of arterial thrombotic phenomena involving the cerebral arteries (eg, cerebrovascular
accidents).

vignette.presentation:
16. A 1-day-old male newborn is evaluated in the hospital nursery before discharge. ver his skull. He was born at term to a 27-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, following an uncomplicated pregnancy and

forceps-assisted delivery. 7 signs are within normal mits. Examination shows a 3 * 3-cm well demarcated area of boggy swelling over the left

parietal skul over the area appears normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate test to screen for potential complications associated with this patient's skull abnormality?

A} Chromosomal microarray test

B}- Determination eHNR

DB} Eehoeardiography

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Assisted vaginal delivery is typically indicated for a prolonged second stage of labor and can be completed using vacuum-assisted devices or metal forceps. Vacuum-assisted devices can cause scalp lacerations, cephalohematoma, brachial
plexus injury due to shoulder dystocia, retinal hemorrhage, and intracranial hemorrhage. Forceps-assisted deliveries carry the risk of cephalohematoma, laceration, intracranial hemorrhage, facial nerve injury, skull fracture, and ocular injury.
This newborn, whose delivery was assisted with forceps, with a large, contained scalp swelling most likely developed a cephalohematoma secondary to his delivery method. Cephalohematomas occur when the blood vessels that supply the
periosteum of the skull are torn, with blood accumulating between the periosteum and skull. Itis not typically readily apparent at birth but rather develops over the course of hours to days. Cephalohematomas commonly present, as they did in
this patient, with a soft area of swelling bordered by cranial suture lines and without evidence of overlying skin changes. They are managed expectantly, with the majority resolving on their own. However, they do put the newborn at increased
risk for the development of jaundice, as the breakdown of blood products overwhelms the neonatal liver's ability to appropriately conjugate the components. Thus, patients with cephalohematoma should have serum bilirubin concentration
measured and be monitored closely for the development of jaundice.
explanation.educational_objective:
Cephalohematomas are common birth injuries, frequently associated with assisted vaginal deliveries. They occur due to traumatic rupture of the blood vessels that supply the periosteum of the skull, resulting in blood
accumulation between the periosteum and cranial bones. They commonly present with a soft area of swelling bordered by cranial suture lines and without evidence of overlying skin changes. Breakdown products of the cephalohematoma can
overwhelm the neonatal liver's ability for conjugation, so these newborns should be screened with measurement of serum bilirubin concentration and observed carefully for the development of jaundice.

vignette.presentation: TBD

17. A37-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She has had hypopituitarism since she underwent surgical excision of a large pituitary tumor followed by radiation therapy 15 years

ago. She says that she is generally doing well but has noticed some increased fatigue, sleepiness, and a 2.3-kg (5-Ib) weight gain during the past 6 months. Medications include levothyroxine, hydrocortisone,

and an oral contraceptive. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. The most appropriate next step in management is measurement of which of the following?

A} 24-Hour- radioactive iedine-uptake
3. concentration

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Measurement of serum free thyroxine (FT4) concentration is the most appropriate next step in management as it provides direct information as to whether this patient is receiving sufficient hormone replacement to
confirm a diagnosis of hypothyroidism. Hypothyroidism is a clinical condition characterized by insufficient production of thyroid hormones (triiodothyronine and thyroxine) by the thyroid gland. Various causes such as
autoimmune disorders, surgery, radiation therapy, or medication-induced hypothyroidism can occur. Deficiency of these hormones leads to a decrease in metabolic rate manifesting as fatigue, weight gain, cold
intolerance, constipation, dry skin, hair loss, and myalgia. Patients that undergo pituitary surgeries are at risk for the development of hypopituitarism, and thus, acquired hypothyroidism. These patients, depending on
the extent of the surgical intervention, will need hormone supplementation for thyroid and adrenal gland function because thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) concentrations
can be too low. Supplementation with levothyroxine and hydrocortisone is common. If these medications are not dosed correctly, symptoms of hypothyroidism and adrenal insufficiency can occur. In this patient with a
history of fatigue, sleepiness, and weight gain, hypothyroidism should be a consideration. Because this patient does not have a functional pituitary gland as a result of surgical and radiation intervention, the typical
endocrine pathways for thyroid hormone secretion are disrupted.
explanation.educational_objective:
Measurement of serum free thyroxine (FT4) concentration can confirm appropriate dosing of levothyroxine and show emergent symptoms of hyperthyroidism in patients receiving hormone
replacement therapy. Acquired hypothyroidism can be seen in patients who undergo surgical or radiation intervention to the pituitary gland. Treatment consists of lifelong thyroid hormone supplementation, the most
common being levothyroxine.

vignette.presentation:
18. A64-year-old man comes to the office to request help for alcohol use disorder. He says he has tried to stop drinking alcohol on his own on a few occasions but has relapsed within several days each time. He
has never had delirium tremens or other severe withdrawal symptoms. He has not consumed alcohol during the past 7 days. He reports no substantial symptoms of alcohol withdrawal at this time. He has
severe degenerative spine disease, for which he is on long-term disability leave. He has been taking prescribed hydrocodone and acetaminophen for 11 years. He does not smoke cigarettes. He has been
drinking six 12-0z beers daily for 9 years. He is divorced and lives alone. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows decreased movement in the low back secondary to pain. No other
abnormalities are noted. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's alcohol use disorder?
B} Bupropion
6} Lerezepam

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Alcohol use disorder refers to an addiction to alcohol that must meet at least two of the following criteria: an inability to cut back on drinking, drinking more than expected, excessive time spent drinking, alcohol
cravings, persistent drinking despite physical or mental problems related to drinking, and persistent drinking despite negative social consequences. Patients with moderate to severe alcohol use disorder may benefit
from daily medication. Commonly used medications include naltrexone, acamprosate, disulfiram, and gabapentin. Naltrexone, an opioid antagonist, would precipitate opioid withdrawal in this patient taking
hydrocodone, an opioid agonist. Therefore, acamprosate, a medication with an unclear mechanism of action that likely involves N-methy!-D-aspartate antagonism, is the best option.
explanation.educational_objective:
Alcohol use disorder is characterized by an inability to cut back on drinking, excessive time spent drinking, and negative consequences related to drinking. Patients with moderate-to-severe
alcohol use disorder may benefit from first-line pharmacotherapy, such as naltrexone, acamprosate, disulfiram, or gabapentin. In patients on opioid agonist therapy, naltrexone should be avoided as it can precipitate
opioid withdrawal, making acamprosate the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient.

vignette.presentation:
19. A27-year-old man comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of shortness of breath with exertion. He has a 1-week history of mild shortness of breath after climbing one flight of stairs. He has not had fever, cough, or weight loss. He does not smoke. He is employed as an
office worker. Vital signs are within normal limits. Jugular venous pressure is 7 cm H,. There is clubbing of the fingers bilaterally. Crackles are heard throughout the lungs. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:
pH 7.44
Poop  34mmHg
Pos’ 62 mm Hg
‘An x-ray of the chest is shown. Pulmonary function tests show a normal FEV ,;FVC ratio and decreased diffusion capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's dyspnea?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
This patient's presentation and diagnostic studies are consistent with a diagnosis of interstitial lung disease (ILD). ILD encompasses a heterogeneous group of disorders that result in pulmonary fibrosis and progressively impaired lung function. Causes include various infections, occupational
and environmental exposures, drug-induced pulmonary toxicity, radiation-induced lung injury, connective tissue disorders, hypersensitivity pneumonitis, and idiopathic disease. Patients typically present with progressive dyspnea and chronic nonproductive cough. Inspiratory crackles and
hypertrophic osteoarthropathy (ie, clubbing) may be present on physical examination. Pulmonary function testing (PFT) will show a normal or increased FEV:FVC ratio, decreased total lung capacity, and decreased diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO). Chest x-ray may
show interstitial opacification in the periphery of the lungs, though radiographic patterns are dependent on the specific underlying cause.
explanation.educational_objective:
Interstitial lung disease (ILD) is an insidious disorder with numerous potential causes that typically presents with progressive dyspnea and nonproductive cough. The presence of ILD is best confirmed with a high-resolution CT scan showing evidence of interstitial fibrosis.
Definitive diagnosis of the underlying cause requires lung biopsy. For a patient who is unable to tolerate biopsy or has milder symptoms, a treatment plan is often determined using clinical risk factors, history of exposures, radiographic patterns, and adjunct testing.

vignette.presentation:
20. A62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a §-kg (11-Ib) weight loss during the past 2 months despite no change in appetite. He has mild hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs
£88 kg (195 Ib); BMI is 28 kg/m?. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min and regular, and blood pressure is 150/94 mm Hg. Examination shows no other abnormalities. Serum studies show:
Na* 135 mEqiL
Kr 3.8 mEq/L
HCO. 25 mEq/L
Glucose 328 mg/dL
Which of the following is the most likely cause of these laboratory findings?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Type 2 diabetes mellitus is a metabolic syndrome defined by progressive insulin resistance and a chronic predisposition to hyperglycemia. Initially, as insulin resistance develops, patients will compensate with increased insulin production. Over time, insulin
resistance will continue to increase and eventually result in decreased insulin production as a result of the bumnout of pancreatic B-cells and their resultant destruction. Type 2 diabetes mellitus has a strong familial predisposition and is generally associated with
obesity, though it can initially be associated with weight-loss as is seen in this patient. Type 2 diabetes mellitus tends to present at above age 40 years old, in contrast with type 1 diabetes mellitus, which predominantly presents in childhood. Treatment for type
2 diabetes mellitus includes lifestyle modifications, oral antidiabetic medications, and occasional insulin injection based on patient response. Given this patient's age and subacute progression of hyperglycemia, the most likely cause of his laboratory findings is
insulin resistance.
explanation.educational_objective:
Type 2 diabetes mellitus is characterized by insulin resistance, hyperglycemia, and progressive insulin deficiency. It tends to present later in life, usually after age 40 years. Treatment includes lifestyle changes, oral antidiabetic agents,
and insulin injection based on patient response.

vignette.presentation:
94. A 12-year-old boy with Crohn disease is brought to the physician because of a 2-week history of fever. His medications are sulfasalazine and prednisone. He is at the 50th percentile for height and 10th percentile for weight. Vital signs
are within normal limits. Examination shows a 7-mm perianal skin tag. There is mild tenderness to palpation over the abdomen. Laboratory studies show:
Hematocrit 35% (N=36%—47%)
Leukocyte count 1000/mm3
Platelet count 200,000/mm3
Serum anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody assay negative
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these laboratory findings?

choices.text: Require the girlfriend to tell the police where he got the cocaine
Require the patient to tell the police where he got the cocaine
Inform his parole officer of his parole violations
Call the police with the information about the drug dealer

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Drug-induced neutropenia from sulfasalazine is the most likely cause of this patient's fever and leukopenia. Other commonly implicated medications include certain cytotoxic chemotherapeutic agents, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, antithyroid
drugs such as methimazole, antipsychotics such as clozapine, and some antiarrhythmic medications. While patients are often asymptomatic, they may present with fever or severe infections and sepsis. Neutrophils normally account for
approximately 40% to 60% of the total leukocyte count on a complete blood count. Neutropenia is defined by an absolute neutrophil count (which includes band forms) of less than 1500/mm®, Agranulocytosis indicates neutrophil counts of less
than 100/mm®. While this patient's neutrophil count is unknown, his total leukocyte count of 1000/mm: is consistent with neutropenia. The risk for spontaneous infection substantially increases when the neutrophil count drops below 500/mm3,
Treatment involves immediate withdrawal of the implicated medication and treatment of any underlying infection. Additionally, granulocyte colony-stimulating factor can sometimes hasten recovery.
explanation.educational_objective:
Drug-induced neutropenia is a common idiosyncratic drug reaction that can put patients at risk for life-threatening infections. The risk for spontaneous infection substantially increases when the neutrophil count drops
below 500/mm3. Withdrawal of the implicated agent in the drug reaction usually resolves the neutropenia.

vignette.presentation:
25. A7-year-old girl is admitted to the intensive care unit because of a §-hour history of confusion, seizures, vomiting, and diarthea. Her mother says the symptoms began suddenly with no known cause. The patient has no history of

serious illness and receives no medications. On examination, she is obtunded. There is dry skin, poor skin turgor, hyperreflexia, and myoclonus. The mother hovers by the patient's bedside and appears to be concerned about caring

for her. For a nonmedical professional, the mother is unusually knowledgeable about medicine, which she demonstrates during frequent conversations with the nursing staff. During the early morning hours on hospital day 1, a nurse

enters the patient's room and finds the mother trying to administer an unknown medication to the patient. Further investigation shows that the mother has a history of psychiatric illness and has been administering her own

psychotropic medication to her daughter. Administration of which of the following medications is the most likely explanation for this patient's presenting symptoms?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Serotonin syndrome, the result of serotonin toxicity, can lead to the triad of acute confusion, autonomic hyperactivity (ie, hyperthermia, tachycardia, hypertension), and neuromuscular excitability (eg, tremor, myoclonus, hyperreflexia). As a
consequence of fever and sweating, patients may become dehydrated and have dry skin and poor skin turgor. As a result of serotonin receptors in the gastrointestinal tract, vomiting and diarrhea can also occur. Though serotonin syndrome can
occur at therapeutic dosages of medications, especially if multiple serotonergic medications are prescribed, the risk increases with overuse, as in this patient whose mother is administering serotonergic medication surreptitiously (meeting
criteria for factitious disorder by proxy). Though serotonergic antidepressants (eg, monoamine oxidase inhibitors, tricyclic antidepressants, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, etc.) are most classically associated with serotonin syndrome,
several other classes of medications also increase serotonin signaling and thus increase serotonin syndrome risk. These medications include mood stabilizers such as lithium carbonate, illicit drugs (eg, ecstasy, lysergic acid), antiemetic
medications (eg, ondansetron), migraine medications (eq, triptans), and opioid medications (eg, meperidine, dextromethorphan, oxycodone, fentanyl). Management of serotonin syndrome includes discontinuation of all serotonergic agents,
supportive care of autonomic instability, sedation with benzodiazepines, intravenous fluid repletion, and cooling measures. Cyproheptadine is an antidote with nonspecific serotonin antagonist properties that can be used, but evidence of
efficacy is mixed.
explanation.educational_objective:
Serotonin syndrome, the result of serotonin toxicity, can lead to the triad of acute confusion, autonomic hyperactivity (ie, hyperthermia, tachycardia, hypertension), and neuromuscular excitability (eg, tremor, myoclonus,
hyperreflexia). In addition to serotonergic antidepressants, lithium carbonate, triptans, antiemetic medications (eg, ondansetron), and illicit drugs (eg, ecstasy) can increase the risk for serotonin syndrome. Management includes discontinuation
of all serotonergic agents, supportive care of autonomic instability, sedation with benzodiazepines, intravenous fluid repletion, and cooling measures. Cyproheptadine is an antidote with nonspecific serotonin antagonist properties that can be
used, but evidence of efficacy is mixed.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment
% 26. 37-year-old man who is a sergeant in the US Army comes to the clinic because of a 4-week history of fever, mild cramping abdominal pain, and occasional bloody diarrhea. During this time, he has had a 3-kg (7-Ib) weight loss
because of decreased appetite. He has not had nausea or vomiting. He has no history of serious illness, has no known allergies, and takes no medications. Four weeks ago, he returned from a deployment to the Caribbean in support
of humanitarian efforts after a natural disaster. During the deployment, he frequently ate food and drank water sold by local street vendors. He appears uncomfortable but is not in acute distress. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse
is 88/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 128/72 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows softness with mild right lower quadrant tendemess. There is no hepatosplenomegaly and no rebound or guarding. The remainder
of the examination shows no abnormalities. Results of laboratory studies are shown:
Hemoglobin 11.4 gidL.
Hematocrit 33%
Leukocyte count 41,000/mms
‘Segmented neutrophils 78%
Bands 2%
Eosinophils 4%
Lymphocytes 15%
Monocytes 1%
Platelet count 210,000/mms
Serum liver enzyme activities and results of a comprehensive serum metabolic panel are within the reference ranges. Which of the following stool studies is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
A} Glestridium-diffieile-assay
B} Gulture
C) Immunochemical test
BD} Leukeeyte-test
Correct Answer: E.
Infection with Entamoeba histolytica leads to amoebiasis (amoebic dysentery). E. histolytica is an amoebic parasite that forms cysts, which can be transmitted through the fecal-oral route, typically through ingestion of contaminated water.
Amoebic cysts mature to trophozoites in the large bowel, which may invade the colonic mucosa and interstitium, leading to symptoms of abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea, or which may enter the bloodstream and cause hepatic amoebic
abscesses, which present with fever and right upper quadrant pain. The diagnosis can be made with identification of cysts on stool ova and parasite examination, which may show trophozoites with endosomes containing red blood cells, as wel
as by antigen assay or polymerase chain reaction testing. Colonoscopy shows mucosal ulcers that are often flask-shaped. Treatment of hepatic amoebic abscesses involves combination therapy with metronidazole or tinidazole, as well as an
anti-luminal agent such as paromomycin or iodoquinol. This patient likely contracted E. histolytica while in the Caribbean when he consumed local food and water.
Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and D.
Clostridium difficile assay (Choice A) is used to assess for C. difficile infection. C. difficile typically presents with frequent watery diarrhea, often occurring after treatment with antibiotics. In this case, the patient is experiencing bloody diarrhea in
the setting of recent travel to the Caribbean, which makes an amoebic infection more likely.
Culture (Choice B) of the stool can aid in the diagnosis of bacterial gastroenteritis. Stool culture can help identify infections with organisms such as Salmonella, Campylobacter, and Shigella. Although Salmonella, Campylobacter, and Shigella
can present with bloody diarrhea, this patient was recently traveling in the Caribbean where E. histolytica is endemic, making it the most likely causal organism.
Immunochemical test (Choice C) helps to identify occult blood in the stool. It is often used to help screen for cases of colon cancer. In this case, the patient is already known to have bloody diarrhea. Because of his recent travel, E. histolytica is
the most likely organism implicated, with workup requiring stool ova and parasite examination.
Leukocyte test (Choice D) can help to identify white blood cells present in the stool. It is not an accurate test for inflammatory diarrhea as it has low- and variable-reported sensitivity and specificity. In cases of E. histolytica, leukocytes are
typically not identified on stool studies as the organism destroys the leukocytes. In this case, E. histolytica is the most likely causal organism, requiring stool ova and parasite examination to confirm the diagnosis.
Educational Objective: Infection with Entamoeba histolytica presents with bloody diarrhea and may lead to invasive amoebiasis including hepatic abscesses. E. histolytica occurs worldwide but occurs much more frequently in resource-limited
areas such as the Caribbean. Evaluation for E. histolytica includes identification of cysts on stool ova and parasite examination, which may show trophozoites with endosomes containing red blood cells, as well as antigen assay or polymerase
chain reaction testing. Treatment involves combination therapy with metronidazole or tinidazole, as well as an anti-luminal agent such as paromomycin or iodoquinol.

vignette.presentation:
27. A32-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because he has fallen several times and has had progressive confusion during the past 3 days. He reports difficulty keeping his balance while walking. He sustained a left
femoral fracture in a motor vehicle collision 3 years ago and a right metacarpal fracture in a fight 1 year ago. He has a history of pancreatitis, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and major depressive disorder. Current medications are
pantoprazole and sertraline. He is oriented to person and place but not to time. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Examination shows difficulty with conjugate gaze and bilateral
weakness on abduction of both eyes. His gait is broad based and ataxic. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13 g/dL
Hematocrit 39%
Mean corpuscular volume 98 um?
Serum
Total bilirubin 1 mg/dL
AST 69 U/L
ALT 65 U/L
‘Supplementation with which of the following would most likely have prevented this patient's current condition?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Wernicke encephalopathy is caused by a deficiency of vitamin B, (thiamine), most commonly in patients with alcohol use disorder, anorexia nervosa, malignancy, or hyperemesis of pregnancy, among other conditions. It presents classically
with encephalopathy, ataxia, and oculomotor dysfunction (eg, nystagmus). This patient's presentation is most consistent with alcohol use disorder and the resultant consequences of it, including aggressive behavior, pancreatitis, and nutritional
deficiencies. Over time, thiamine deficiency can result in damage and atrophy of the mammillary bodies, visible on MRI of the brain, which manifests as Wernicke encephalopathy. The typical clinical presentation of Wernicke encephalopathy is.
a triad of acute altered mental status (eg, disorientation), ophthalmoplegia/nystagmus, and ataxia. The symptoms of Wernicke encephalopathy are reversible but increase the risk for developing Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome (also known as
Korsakoff psychosis) in patients with chronic alcohol use disorders if not immediately treated with high-dose intravenous thiamine therapy. Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is an irreversible condition that features anterograde and retrograde
amnesia along with the consequent tendency to confabulate or verbalize false stories or memories in order to compensate for the inability to remember. Prevention of the progression to Wernicke encephalopathy includes thiamine
supplementation, whereas treatment consists of intravenous thiamine administration. If left untreated, it can lead to coma and death. The patient's alcohol use should specifically be addressed as well to prevent further episodes and worsening.
This is best addressed once the patient is no longer altered and on a long-term basis with a multidisciplinary approach led by the primary care physician.
explanation.educational_objective:
Wernicke encephalopathy presents with ataxia, oculomotor dysfunction, and encephalopathy caused by a deficiency of vitamin B, (thiamine). It is most commonly seen in those with chronic malnutrition, such as those
with alcohol use disorder or systemic malignancy. Prevention and treatment include the administration of thiamine.

vignette.presentation:
28. An 11-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents because he has refused to attend school during the past 2 months. His parents say he has become increasingly anxious during this time. He has
refused to give them an explanation for why he is avoiding school. The patient received 4 months of psychotherapy at the age of 8 years because he insisted on changing his shirt several times before
leaving the house to go to school and was always late. According to the parents, he was diagnosed with an anxiety disorder, and his shirt-changing behavior stopped after 10 sessions. He has no other
history of serious illness and receives no medications. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. When interviewed alone, the patient explains to the physician that, “My mother has developed diabetes,
and I cannot get it out of my head that she will die if | go to school.” He adds that several times daily, he checks to make sure there is enough insulin in the house. Which of the following is the most likely
diagnosis?
A} Delusional diserder

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is an anxiety disorder typically characterized by obsessions that the patient attempts to neutralize with compulsions. Obsessions are unwanted, intrusive thoughts (eg, thoughts
related to harm, health, violence, sex, or contamination) or urges (eg, to commit violence) that increase anxiety. Compulsions are rigidly applied repetitive behaviors (eg, checking, washing, changing clothes) or
mental activities (eg, counting, repeating words) that relieve anxiety related to obsessions. The compulsions are excessive or do not realistically address the obsessive fears, and patients commonly recognize the
irrationality of their compulsions. It is common for the nature of obsessions and compulsions to evolve over time, as seen with this patient. The pathogenesis of OCD is likely multifactorial, related to genetics, stress,
and/or dysfunction of striatal and thalamic circuits. The age of onset is commonly in childhood or adolescence. Treatment includes high doses of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (eg, fluoxetine) or cognitive
behavioral therapy with a focus on exposure to the discomfort of suppressing the compulsion after experiencing the obsession.
explanation.educational_objective:
Obsessive-compulsive disorder is an anxiety disorder typically characterized by obsessions (eg, unwanted, intrusive thoughts that produce anxiety) that the patient attempts to neutralize with
compulsions (eg, repetitive behaviors). The compulsions are excessive or do not realistically address the obsessive fears.
a C e @ € © m

vignette.presentation:
30. A57-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the physician 3 weeks after noticing a mass in her right breast during self-examination. Ten years ago, she underwent stereotactic biopsy of the left breast that showed a benign adenoma. Menarche
was at the age of 13 years, and menses occurred at regular 28-day intervals until menopause 6 years ago. She delivered her first child at the age of 28 years. The patient's matemal aunt had breast cancer diagnosed at the age of 67 years.
Examination of the patient's right breast shows a 3-cm, fixed, tender, solid mass in the upper outer quadrant. No regional lymphadenopathy is palpated. Examination of the left breast shows a faint surgical scar but no other abnormalities. Which of the
following is the strongest predisposing risk factor for breast cancer in this patient?

choices.text: Age when her first child was born

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Breast cancer is the most common nondermatologic malignancy in patients assigned female at birth and commonly presents with a breast mass, skin or nipple retraction, or axillary lymphadenopathy. However, it may also be asymptomatic and diagnosed on
screening mammography. Risk factors for breast cancer development include advanced age or postmenopausal status, exogenous estrogen administration, a family history of premenopausal breast cancer, genetic mutations (eg, BRCA1 and BRCA2), early
menarche, late menopause, nulliparity, and obesity. Advanced age is the most common risk factor for the development of breast cancer, with the incidence of breast cancer increasing greatly with age. This patient is postmenopausal, which makes her current
age her strongest predisposing risk factor for breast cancer. Additionally, she had appropriately timed menarche, menopause, and childbirth, and has no significant personal or family history of breast cancer. Evaluation of a palpable breast mass first involves,
mammography depending on the age of the patient, and core-needle biopsy of lesions that are concerning for breast cancer. Treatment of breast cancer depends on the clinical stage and may involve surgical excision, chemotherapy, or radiation.
explanation.educational_objective:
Breast cancer is the most common nondermatologic malignancy in patients assigned female at birth. It may cause a palpable breast mass, disclosed on routine screening mammography, or cause symptoms of metastatic disease. Risk
factors for its development include advanced age or postmenopausal status, exogenous estrogen administration, a family history of premenopausal breast cancer, genetic mutations (eg, BRCA1 and BRCA2), early menarche, late menopause, nulliparity, and
obesity, with advanced age being the most common risk factor. Diagnosis includes ultrasonography or mammography and core-needle biopsy. Treatment of breast cancer depends on the clinical stage and may involve surgical excision, chemotherapy, or
radiation.

3. There is scant axillary hair. Examination shows no other findings. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's breast development?

choices.text: Ingestion of the mother's oral contraceptive
Physical therapy for motion and strength
Surgical debridement of the hip joint

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Puberty refers to the normal hormonal and physiologic changes that occur as children age. The most common age range for the onset of puberty in females is age 9 to 12 years, although this can vary based on factors such as body weight, genetics, and
ethnicity. Precocious puberty refers to the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years in females or 9 years in males. It can be idiopathic or caused by a variety of conditions, such as central nervous system lesions, ovarian or germ cell
tumors, adrenal disorders, or genetic defects, such as McCune-Albright syndrome. Normal pubertal development in females often starts with breast development, followed by pubic hair development and menarche. This patient is progressing through normal
pubertal milestones at an appropriate age, and no further workup is necessary. Reassurance is the most appropriate next step in management.
explanation.educational_objective:
Normal pubertal development most commonly occurs between ages 9 and 12 years in females. Puberty typically begins with breast development, followed by pubic hair development and menarche. The development of secondary
sexual characteristics prior to age 8 in females is referred to as precocious puberty and warrants further evaluation with a thorough history and physical examination, as well as laboratory studies. Normal pubertal development does not require additional
workup.

Exam Section 1: Item 32 of 50 National Board of Medical Examiners®
Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment
. A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a 2-day history of increasingly severe pain of his right leg with an associated limp. He has not fallen or sustained any
Y 32 A4 Id boy is bi ht to th depart it by his its b if a 2-day hist fi ingl in of his right | ith jated li He hi fall lined
trauma. One week ago, he was treated with amoxicillin for a middle ear infection. He has no history of serious illness and currently takes no medications. He is at the 50th percentile for height and weight.
Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, the patient holds the right hip flexed and externally rotated. Passive range of motion of the right hip is limited by pain. An x-ray of the right hip shows no.
abnormalities. His leukocyte count is 10,000/mm5, erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 15 mm/h, and serum C-reactive protein concentration is 1.5 mg/L (N=0.08-3.1). Which of the following is the most
appropriate treatment for this patient?
A) Intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy
C) Physical therapy for motion and strength
E) Surgical debridement of the hip joint
Correct Answer: B.
The most likely diagnosis in this otherwise healthy patient is transient synovitis of the hip. Transient synovitis is an inflammatory condition involving the synovial lining of weight-bearing joints, with the hip being
commonly affected. It classically presents in children recovering from a viral infection. Symptoms include pain when bearing weight, antalgic gait, refusal to ambulate, tenderness over the affected joint, and pain
elicited with range of motion. Vital signs are generally within normal limits, as are laboratory studies apart from increased markers of inflammation, such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Antecedent viral infection
has been reported in up to 30% of cases of transient synovitis. Diagnosis involves the exclusion of emergent or urgent conditions, such as cellulitis, septic arthritis, osteomyelitis, and fracture. In this case, the patient
does not exhibit symptoms of infection, and laboratory studies show a leukocyte count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and C-reactive protein within normal limits. Treatment is supportive and involves rest and
nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. If there is diagnostic uncertainty, arthrocentesis should be performed to exclude septic arthritis, along with imaging studies to assess for osteomyelitis or fracture.
Incorrect Answers: A, C, D, and E.
Intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy (Choice A) would be indicated in cases of septic arthritis or osteomyelitis. In this case, the patient most likely has transient synovitis of the hip as vital signs and results
of laboratory studies are within normal limits. Initial broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy in cases of septic arthritis or osteomyelitis should include vancomycin because of its effectiveness against Staphylococcus
aureus.
Physical therapy for motion and strength (Choice C) is a conservative treatment option for hip pain. This patient likely has transient synovitis which often resolves in an acute to subacute time frame. Nonsteroidal
anti-inflammatory drug therapy is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient due to the self-limiting nature of transient synovitis and prompt pain relief.
Serial hip joint aspirations (Choice D) is a treatment option for septic arthritis. After joint aspiration is performed, Gram stain and culture can be performed on the synovial fluid to evaluate for septic arthritis and to
determine antibiotic sensitivities if the joint is found to be infected.
Surgical debridement of the hip joint (Choice E) is also a treatment option for septic arthritis. It can be performed either initially or after joint aspiration if rapid improvement is not achieved. This patient's laboratory
studies and vital signs are within normal limits making transient synovitis the most likely diagnosis.
Educational Objective: Transient synovitis is an inflammatory condition involving the synovial lining of weight-bearing joints, with the hip being frequently affected. Symptoms are transient and the most appropriate
treatment is nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug therapy. It is important to rule out emergent or urgent conditions, such as cellulitis, septic arthritis, osteomyelitis, and fracture.

vignette.presentation:
33. AQ-month-old boy is brought to the office by his parents because they are concerned about swelling in his abdomen that has been present since birth and has increased during the past 2 weeks. The

patient's diet consists of cow milk-based formula, baby food, and some solid food. He has six wet diapers and one bowel movement daily. He has no history of serious illness and receives no medications.

He is at the 75th percentile for length, weight, and head circumference. Vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination shows a 2-cm protrusion from the umbilicus that is easily reducible; there

is no erythema, induration, or tenderness to palpation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
An umbilical hernia occurs due to failure of spontaneous closure of the umbilical ring. Following birth, the umbilical ring is progressively closed by the rectus abdominis muscles and is accompanied by fusion of the
muscular fascial layers and of the peritoneal membrane. Complete closure occurs in most children during infancy. The majority of children with an umbilical hernia experience spontaneous resolution by age 3 years,
but children with large defects or persistent defects are less likely to experience spontaneous closure and may undergo progressive enlargement of the defect over time. Umbilical hernias are associated with
hypothyroidism, Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, trisomy 18 and 21, and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. A minority of patients may require surgical intervention if intestinal incarceration develops or if defects persist
beyond age 4 years. This patient does not require further intervention as there are no concerning findings identified on history and physical examination.

vignette.presentation: TBD

explanation.educational_objective:
Umbilical hernias are due to failure of spontaneous closure of the umbilical ring. The majority of children have spontaneous resolution by age 3 years. Umbilical hernias are associated with
hypothyroidism, Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, trisomy 18 and 21, and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. A minority of patients with umbilical hernia may require surgical intervention when large defects (greater than 1.5
cm), intestinal incarceration, or behavioral concerns are present. Surgery is generally recommended after age 4 years due to spontaneous resolution often occurring by age 3 and high risk for recurrence if surgery is
completed at a younger age.

vignette.presentation:
34. Apediatric clinic implements a screening test for determining alcohol use in adolescent patients. The screening test has an 85% sensitivity and 95% specificity. A 15-year-old boy has a positive result prior to

being examined by the physician. The prevalence of alcohol use in the adolescent patients in this clinic is 10%. Which of the following best explains how the positive result on the screening test affects the

probability that this patient consumes alcohol?

B} Deereases substantially

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Likelihood ratio (LR) describes the probability of a given test result in a patient with a particular disease or condition under study divided by the probability of that result in a patient without the disease. This can be
conceptualized as LR = true positives / false positives, or TP / FP. LR is related to similar measures of sensitivity and specificity. Sensitivity is the ability of a test to detect a disease if it is present. High sensitivity is
therefore useful in ruling out a disease. Sensitivity can be calculated by the equation: Sensitivity = (true positives) / (true positives + false negatives), or TP/(TP + FN). Specificity is the proportion of people who do
not have the disease who test negative. High specificity is useful in ruling in a disease. Specificity can be calculated by the equation: Specificity = (true negatives) / (true negatives + false positives), or TN / (TN +
FP). LR, sensitivity, and specificity are all independent of disease prevalence, although they are impacted by the severity of the disease under study (with more severe diseases being easier to detect). Some
statistical measures, including positive predictive value (PPV) and negative predictive value (NPV), are impacted by disease prevalence. In this example, the screening test for alcohol use shows a high degree of
sensitivity and specificity, which suggests that its proportion of TP and TN results is high in comparison to its proportion of FP and FN results. A test with a high ratio of TP to FP indicates a substantial increase in the
likelihood of the disease being present, given the positive test result.
explanation.educational_objective:
Likelihood ratio (LR) describes the probability of a given test result in a patient with a particular disease under study divided by the probability of that result in a patient without the disease. This
can be conceptualized as LR = true positives / false positives, or TP / FP. LR is related to similar measures of sensitivity and specificity. LR, sensitivity, and specificity are all independent of disease prevalence. In
general, when given a test with high sensitivity and specificity, a positive result carries a high likelihood of disease being present.

vignette.presentation:
87. Astudy is conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of testing stool for occult blood. One thousand men between the ages of 45 and 60 years who come to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination are enrolled in the
study. Results show that 70 of 100 patients with colon cancer have a positive test of the stool for occult blood, and 720 of 900 patients without colon cancer have a negative test of the stool for occult blood. Which of the following is the
most accurate conclusion regarding this study?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Prevalence, as applied to biostatistics, defines the number of cases of a disease or condition as a fraction of a population in consideration at a point in time. Prevalence, therefore, indicates the percentage of current cases of a condition within
the population under study. The prevalence of a disease may change over time or vary between populations. Mathematically, prevalence is calculated by dividing the number of existing cases by the number of people in the population under
study or at risk for the condition. In this case, the condition or disease under study is colon cancer, and the population in question is men between ages 45 and 60 years. Based on the data given, prevalence therefore equals 100 (the number
of men with colon cancer)/1000 (the number of men in the study). Prevalence should also be distinguished from incidence. Incidence is the number of new cases expressed as a percentage of the total population at risk over a specified period.
explanation.educational_objective:
Prevalence defines the number of existing cases of a disease or condition as a percentage of the number of people in the population under study who are at risk for that condition. The prevalence of a disease may
change over time or vary between populations. Prevalence should be distinguished from incidence, which is the number of new cases expressed as a percentage of the total population at risk over a specified period.

38. Amedical director of Itisite internal medici ct ts te imize deli f ti ices to patients. Th tice has fi it h loyi

lead physician, one office manager, and 50 internists. Which of the following strategies is most likely to be effective?

choices.text: Determination of an action plan by each site's lead physician
Educational program at a central location regarding the importance of preventive services
Educational program at each site regarding the importance of preventive services

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Quality improvement is a framework that seeks to systematically improve and standardize the performance of a medical practice. Quality improvement hinges on plan-do-study-act
(PDSA) cycles, an iterative process in which providers plan an intervention, execute the intervention, study the intervention using quality measures, and identify successes and
areas of improvement for the next cycle. Quality measures that are timely and patient-centered are crucial. The medical director should first formulate a plan. Healthcare delivery is
complex, and the implementation of changes requires teamwork across disciplines. As such, quality improvement efforts require collaboration from multiple disciplines, including
physicians, nurses, social workers, administrators, and even statisticians and epidemiologists. This variety of stakeholders should be present at the initial planning meeting to build
buy-in and develop a plan for increasing preventive care that is feasible for all disciplines. Similarly, if a quality improvement effort will span multiple sites, representatives from each
site should be involved in the planning meeting so that the needs of each site are addressed.
explanation.educational_objective:
Quality improvement seeks to systematically improve and standardize the performance of a medical practice, and it hinges on plan-do-study-act cycles.
When formulating a plan, medical directors should form a planning team with stakeholders from multiple disciplines and sites. These stakeholders need to buy into the intervention
and assist with implementation.

vignette.presentation:
40. A2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 1-week history of rectal tissue protruding from his anus when he strains vigorously during bowel

movements. The tissue retracts spontaneously within 1 hour. His mother notes that his stools are hard. He has no history of serious illness and receives no medications.

Immunizations are up-to-date. Growth and development are appropriate for age. The patient's paternal uncle has a history of intermittent abdominal pain and diarrhea; he

recently began a gluten-free diet on the advice of a friend. The patient's family dog recently was treated for worms. Examination of the patient shows no abnormalities; the

anus appears normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptom?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Functional constipation is the most common cause of constipation in healthy children. Pediatric patients commonly develop functional constipation after the introduction of solid
foods to their diet, during toilet training, and when beginning school. Pathologic causes of pediatric constipation include congenital megacolon (Hirschsprung disease), spina bifida,
hypothyroidism, cystic fibrosis, and diabetes insipidus, which should be excluded by a careful history and physical examination. Red flag signs that suggest a pathologic cause of
constipation include onset of constipation prior to 1 month of age, delayed passage of meconium, failure to thrive, abdominal distension, intermittent diarrhea or explosive stools, an|
empty rectal vault, and midline hair or pigmentary changes over the lumbar spine. Imaging and laboratory studies are usually not necessary for most children. Treatment of
constipation includes osmotic or polyethylene glycol-based laxatives and dietary modification with increased intake of fluids and fiber. Manual disimpaction or enema administration
may be required in refractory cases. This patient likely has functional constipation as he does not have a previous medical history and does not have any concerning signs
identified on physical examination.
explanation.educational_objective:
Functional constipation is the most common cause of constipation in healthy children. A child is most likely to develop functional constipation after the
introduction of solid foods, during toilet training, and when beginning school. It is important to conduct a thorough history and physical examination to rule out pathological causes of
constipation, including congenital megacolon (Hirschsprung disease), spina bifida, hypothyroidism, cystic fibrosis, and diabetes insipidus. Treatment of functional constipation
includes osmotic or polyethylene glycol-based laxatives and dietary modification with increased intake of fluids and fiber.

vignette.presentation:
41. A32-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He was admitted to the hospital 2 months ago for treatment of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia

and received the diagnosis of HIV infection at that time. After discharge from the hospital, he completed his antibiotic course but missed scheduled follow-up

appointments. He currently takes no medications. He says he feels well. Examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in

management?

A} ReferralHte-anether physieian-due-te-noneemplianee-with- medical therapy

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Pneumocystis jirovecii is an opportunistic, yeast-like fungal organism that can cause pneumonia in immunocompromised patients, including those with poorly controlled HIV
infection. Chest imaging typically shows diffuse, bilateral infiltrates often prominent about the hila. Methenamine silver or toluidine blue stains selectively stain the cyst walls and are.
used to confirm the diagnosis. Patients with HIV infection who have CD4+ counts below 200 cells/mm? are at risk for developing pneumonia from P. jirovecii. Given this patient's
lack of current antiretroviral therapy and recent history of P. jirovecii, prophylaxis against recurrence is indicated. Treatment consists of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX),
atovaquone, or pentamidine, with TMP-SMX serving as first-line preventive therapy for patients with HIV infection and a CD4+ count <200/mm?. All patients with a newly diagnosed
HIV infection should also be started on three-drug antiretroviral therapy.
explanation.educational_objective:
Pneumocystis jirovecii is an opportunistic, yeast-like fungal organism that can cause pneumonia in immunocompromised patients, particularly those with HIV]
infection and CD4+ counts below 200 cells/mm®. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is the first-line agent for prophylaxis in susceptible patients; atovaquone and pentamidine are
second-line agents.

vignette.presentation:
42. A37-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of malnutrition secondary to systemic sclerosis (scleroderma). Six months ago, she had an elective abortion
because of her poor medical condition and has had a 9-kg (20-Ib) weight loss since that time. She says she has difficulty falling asleep; she awakens daily at 4 am and
cannot go back to sleep. She is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 48 kg (105 Ib); BMI is 16 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. On mental status
examination, she is sad and tearful and reports feeling hopeless. Her serum albumin concentration is 2.2 g/dL. In addition to aggressive nutritional support, which of the
following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
This patient meets criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD). Symptoms include 2 or more weeks of at least five of the following symptoms: depressed mood, anhedonia, guilt or|
worthlessness, difficulty concentrating, psychomotor delay, suicidal thoughts, and/or neurovegetative symptoms (eg, decreased energy, sleep disturbance, appetite disturbance
leading to weight changes). These symptoms disrupt everyday functioning. MDD is common in patients with autoimmune diseases, such as systemic sclerosis, where inflammation
has been implicated in the pathogenesis. Symptoms of MDD and systemic autoimmune diseases commonly overlap (eg, fatigue, decreased appetite), making the two conditions
difficult to distinguish. However, a sad, tearful mood and hopelessness are psychological symptoms that are somewhat specific to MDD and can assist physicians with determining
a diagnosis. Also, this patient's symptoms began after an abortion, which appears to have been a major stressor. Abortions have been associated with onset of major depressive
disorder symptoms in some patients. Treatment of MDD should include psychotherapy and antidepressant pharmacotherapy. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, such as
sertraline, are first-line antidepressant medications because of their effectiveness and benign side effect profiles.
explanation.educational_objective:
Major depressive disorder (MDD) includes 2 or more weeks of five of the following symptoms: depressed mood, anhedonia, guilt or worthlessness, difficulty
concentrating, psychomotor delay, suicidal thoughts, and/or neurovegetative symptoms (eg, decreased energy, sleep disturbance, appetite disturbance). Psychological symptoms,
such as a sad, tearful mood and hopelessness, can distinguish symptoms of MDD from systemic medical illness.
