vignette.presentation:
43. A72-year-old man comes to the office for a routine examination. He underwent carotid endarterectomy and five-vessel coronary artery bypass grafting 1 and 5 years ago, respectively. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, chronic kidney disease, and gastroesophageal reflux disease.
Medications are clopidogrel, hydrochlorothiazide, metoprolol, atorvastatin, famotidine, and aspirin. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 50 years. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 62/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 184/96 mm Hg. Examination
shows no other abnormalities. Results of laboratory studies are shown:
Hemoglobin 13.6 gid
Hematocrit 44%
Leukocyte count 8500/mm?
Serum
Na* 134 mEq/L
ke 4.4 mEq/L
cr 98 mEq/L
HCO,” 24 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 22 mg/dL.
Creatinine 1.5 mg/dL.
Lisinopril is added to the medication regimen. Two weeks later, the patient returns to the physician for a follow-up visit. Pulse is 64/min, and blood pressure is 136/84 mm Hg. Examination is otherwise unchanged. Results of laboratory studies are shown:
Serum
Urea nitrogen 46 mg/dL
Creatinine 3.6 mg/dL
Urine
Blood none
Protein none
Hyaline casts O-t/hpf
Which of the following is the most likely cause of the change in renal function in this patient?
DB} Renal-vein-thrombesis

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Renal artery stenosis causes secondary hypertension related to activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Low afferent blood flow to the affected kidney leads to abnormal stimulation of the juxtaglomerular apparatus and excessive production of renin. Renin converts
angiotensinogen to angiotensin |, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) in the pulmonary vasculature. Angiotensin Il is a potent vasoconstrictor that directly mediates systemic hypertension via increased sodium reabsorption in the renal tubules,
aldosterone and vasopressin release, increased adrenergic tone, and stimulation of hypothalamic thirst centers. In younger patients, fibromuscular dysplasia is the most common cause of renal artery stenosis, while in older patients it is typically caused by atherosclerosis. This patient likely has
bilateral renal artery stenosis due to atherosclerosis, as evidenced by his history of carotid endarterectomy and coronary artery bypass grafting. An abdominal bruit may be appreciated in the region of the stenosis. Diagnosis is established with renal artery Doppler ultrasonography or MRI, which
can quantify the degree of renal artery stenosis and associated kidney atrophy. Treatment involves angioplasty or stenting of the stenosed renal artery to improve flow. ACE inhibitors can be considered for unilateral stenosis. In the setting of bilateral renal artery stenosis, however, use of ACE
inhibitors will decrease systemic hypertension but will lead to acute kidney failure, as evidenced by the acutely increased serum urea nitrogen and creatinine concentrations in this patient following initiation of lisinopril.
explanation.educational_objective:
Renal artery stenosis causes secondary hypertension due to abnormal activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. ACE inhibitors can be considered for unilateral stenosis but can lead to acute kidney failure in the setting of bilateral renal artery stenosis.

44, 62-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 3, comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a painless mass protruding from her vagina with bowel movements. She has the sensation of incomplete emptying of the bladder unless
she pushes the mass back into her vagina. During the past 5 years, she has had increased pelvic pressure with prolonged standing or lifting. She does not have urine loss when coughing or laughing. She has no history of serious.
illness and takes no medications. All her pregnancies ended in uncomplicated vaginal deliveries. The patient is 160 cm (6 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 50 kg (110 Ib); BMI is 20 kg/m2 Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the
mass is shown. Examination shows no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A) Bartholin gland cyst

C) Leiomyoma uteri

D) Urethral diverticulum

E) Uterine sarcoma
Correct Answer: B.
Pelvic organ prolapse (POP) occurs secondary to pelvic floor dysfunction and weakness, resulting in herniation of abdominopelvic organs which causes mass effect and protrusion along the vaginal wall. The herniation of these pelvic organs
can lead to pelvic pressure, as well as urinary, defecatory, and sexual dysfunction. POP is a spectrum of diseases, with complete procidentia being a severe form that includes herniation of the entire anterior, posterior, and apical vaginal
‘compartments through the introitus. The patient will have a degree of cystocele (ie, bladder prolapse), rectocele (ie, rectal prolapse), and enterocele (ie, intestinal prolapse), respectively, as a result of the descent of the pelvic organs. In these
extreme cases, the cervix and uterus may be entirely or partially visible at the introitus. However, patients can have less severe forms with isolated prolapse, such as the cystocele seen in this patient. Cystocele is common in multiparous
patients and is associated with stress or overflow urinary incontinence and the inability to fully empty the bladder. In severe cystoceles, the anterior vaginal wall may hemniate through the introitus, leading to a palpable or visible mass at the
introitus that may enlarge as intra-abdominal pressure increases. Other risk factors for POP include advancing age and obesity. Diagnosis of POP is made through a complete physical examination, and treatment includes pelvic floor
exercises, vaginal pessaries, and surgical repair.
Incorrect Answers: A, C, D, and E.
Bartholin gland cyst (Choice A) is caused by an obstruction of a Bartholin gland, one of which is located on each side of the introitus and provides secretions that lubricate the vagina. It presents with a small area of painful, fluctuant swelling
‘over the posterior aspect of the labium majus. With ongoing obstruction and inflammation, infection and Bartholin gland abscess can develop. It would not be expected to cause a mass that protrudes from the introitus with increased intra-
abdominal pressure, nor would it be expected to cause an inability to empty the bladder.
Leiomyoma uteri (Choice C) are common benign tumors of the uterine smooth muscle. When symptomatic, they can cause abnormal uterine bleeding, pelvic pain, or reproductive dysfunction. Physical examination shows an enlarged,
irregularly shaped uterus. They are estrogen-responsive and thus typically decrease in size with menopause. As they are formed from the uterine myometrium, it would be unlikely that they would be visible at the introitus, especially in this
Patient who is postmenopausal.
Urethral diverticulum (Choice D) is a small outpouching of the urethra that presents with recurrent urinary tract infections, urethritis, urinary incontinence, and incomplete bladder emptying. It would not cause the large external pelvic mass
‘seen on this patient.
Uterine sarcoma (Choice E) is a rare uterine cancer that typically develops from the myometrium or connective tissue of the uterus. Symptoms include abnormal uterine bleeding, abdominopelvic pain, pelvic pressure, and abdominal
distension. This patient has no uterine bleeding or abdominopelvic pain. Additionally, as the sarcoma is formed from the uterine tissues, it would be unlikely to be visibly extruding from the vaginal introitus.
Educational Objective: Pelvic organ prolapse occurs secondary to pelvic floor dysfunction weakness, which results in the herniation of abdominopelvic organs through the vaginal wall. Complete procidentia is a severe form of pelvic organ
prolapse that includes herniation of the entire anterior, posterior, and apical vaginal compartments through the introitus, although less severe forms with isolated prolapse of individual organs can occur. One example is a cystocele, which is
caused by herniation of the bladder through the anterior vaginal wall, most commonly in multiparous patients. It is associated with stress or overflow incontinence, pelvic pressure, and the inability to fully empty the bladder. In severe cases, it
‘can cause herniation of the anterior vaginal wall through the introitus.

vignette.presentation:
45. A 1-day-old male newborn is evaluated in the hospital nursery. He was born at term to a 23-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, following an uncomplicated pregnancy and spontaneous vaginal
delivery. Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. He has been bottle-fed but feeds slowly. On examination of the patient's mother, grip strength is 4/5, and she has difficulty
releasing her grip. The mother is adopted; her and the father's family medical histories are unknown. The patient does not appear to be in distress. He is at the 45th percentile for length,
75th percentile for weight, and 50th percentile for head circumference. His temperature is 35.7°C (96.2°F), pulse is 132/min, respirations are 36/min, and blood pressure is 82/45 mm Hg. Pulse
oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. He does not have a vigorous suck or loud cry. On passive range of motion, muscle tone is decreased throughout. Spontaneous
movements are decreased when the patient is awake. Moro reflex is poor. Deep tendon reflexes are absent. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is
the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Myotonic dystrophy is a genetic disorder caused by expansion of a trinucleotide repeat, which occurs when a series of three nucleotides in repetition are replicated incorrectly and too many repeats are
included in the replicated product. Other conditions caused by trinucleotide repeat expansions include Fragile X syndrome, Huntington disease, and Friedrich ataxia. Myotonic dystrophy has several
phenotypes, but all are characterized by muscle weakness and myotonia, defined as delayed relaxation following a normal contraction of the muscle (as evidenced by the patient's mother having difficulty
releasing her grip). Classic myotonic dystrophy presents between ages 10 and 30 years with muscle weakness, myotonia, cataracts, frontal balding, cardiac arrhythmias, and hypogonadism. However,
symptom onset at birth is also common and can include hypotonia (resulting in quiet cry, poor Moro reflex, absence of reflexes), respiratory difficulties, feeding problems, and delayed development. The
most frequently affected muscles include the facial muscles, sternocleidomastoid, distal forearm muscles, intrinsic hand muscles, and ankle dorsiflexors. Life expectancy is slightly reduced for patients
with classic myotonic dystrophy and premature death is most commonly caused by respiratory or cardiac dysfunction.
explanation.educational_objective:
Myotonic dystrophy is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness, myotonia, cataracts, frontal balding, cardiac arrhythmias, and hypogonadism. Though
feeding and breathing problems are common in many myopathies, myotonia (defined as dysfunctional muscle relaxation) distinguishes myotonic dystrophy from other myopathies. Life expectancy is
slightly reduced for patients with classic myotonic dystrophy and premature death is most commonly caused by respiratory or cardiac dysfunction.

vignette.presentation:
46. An 88-year-old woman remains hospitalized 1 day after undergoing an 8-hour total hip replacement. She is 163 om (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (169 Ib); BMI is 29 kgim2. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 73/min, respirations are 12/min,
and blood pressure is 152/89 mm Hg. Examination shows edema of the left gluteus maximus and palsy of the sciatic nerve. A urinary catheter is in place and contains red-colored urine. Laboratory studies show:
Serum
Na* 138 mEqiL
Kr 6 mEq/L
cr 98 mEq/L
Hco,- 20 mEq/L.
Caz 8 mg/dL.
Creatinine 2mgidL
Creatine kinase 20,000 U/L
Phosphorus 4.0 mg/dL.
Alkaline phosphatase 110 UL
Urine
Blood 2+
Protein 2+
RBC 4lhpt
wec O/hpf
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Elevation of the left lower extremity

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Rhabdomyolysis refers to the abnormal breakdown of skeletal muscle tissue that can occur from multiple causes, the most common of which are crush/compression injuries along with prolonged immobility, excessive exertion, alcohol use, medication, and
exposure to toxic substances. The breakdown of skeletal muscle myocytes results in the release of myoglobin and creatine kinase into systemic circulation. Increased creatine kinase activity can be used as a marker to evaluate for the presence and progression
of rhabdomyolysis. The abnormal release of myoglobin can cause nephrotoxicity, leading to an acute kidney injury from acute tubular necrosis. This patient has electrolyte derangements including hyperkalemia, also common in rhabdomyolysis, as intracellular
ions are released to the interstitial space and ultimately returned to circulation. Hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia, and hypocalcemia are common disturbances in rhabdomyolysis. Treatment of rhabdomyolysis requires supportive care and
intravenous fluid hydration, making the administration of intravenous 0.9% saline the most appropriate next step for this patient. This intervention will assist in the clearance of myoglobin from the kidneys plus restoration of normal electrolyte balance, limiting
nephrotoxicity. In cases where hyperkalemia is present, an ECG should be obtained to assess cardiac electrical disturbances that may require emergent treatment.
explanation.educational_objective:
Rhabdomyolysis is an acute breakdown of muscle tissue leading to increased concentrations of serum myoglobin and electrolyte derangements (eg, hyperkalemia). This may occur in healthy adults after periods of intense physical activity,
It may also occur in patients with seizure disorders and in patients who have fallen or sustained prolonged compression of muscle. Major complications include hyperkalemia and acute tubular necrosis. Treatment is supportive, beginning with intravenous fluid
hydration.

47. A67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of confusion. His wife says he is forgetful and disoriented to time and place. He has small cell carcinoma of the lung, type 2 diabetes melitus, and hypertension. His
medications are lisinopril and metformin. He smoked one and one-half packs of cigarettes daily for 45 years but quit 5 years ago. He drinks six to seven 12-oz beers weekly. On arrival, he has a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. He is unarousable. His,
blood pressure is 136/76 mm Hg; other vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows normal skin turgor; there is no edema. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Laboratory studies show:
Serum
Na* 110 mEq/L
ke 3.5 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 10 mg/dL
Glucose 220 mg/dL.
Creatinine 0.8 mg/d.
Uric acid 3.6 mg/dl.
Urine
Sodium 60 mEqi/L.
Osmolality 650 mOsmol/kg HO
Following admission to the hospital, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Given that this patient arrives to the emergency department (ED) with a generalized tonic-clonic seizure and is unarousable, the most appropriate next step in management is intravenous administration of 3% saline. The goal of this administration is to restore
eunatremia as acute hyponatremia is the likely precipitant of the seizure. Caution must be taken when considering the rate at which to administer hypertonic saline. A rapid increase in serum sodium concentration in a patient with chronic hyponatremia can
cause osmotic demyelination syndrome (QDS), also known as central pontine myelinolysis. For patients with acute hyponatremia, this is less of a concern of ODS, though it must be taken into consideration. According to the American Society of Nephrology, the
safe rate of correction for chronic hyponatremia is generally considered to be less than 12 mEq/L in 24 hours or less than 18 mEq/L in 48 hours. However, when the serum sodium concentration is less than 120 mEq/L, the correction should not exceed 8 mEq/L
in 24 hours to avoid ODS. When acute neurologic symptoms are present, initial correction should only be to the point where neurologic symptoms resolve, followed by slow gradual correction to reach eunatremia thereafter. In general, a bolus of hypertonic
saline sufficient to raise the serum sodium by 4-6 mEq/L is enough to prevent further neurologic symptoms, such as seizures, though this number is clinically variable. Treatment should be targeted to the patient's specific signs and symptoms. Paraneoplastic
syndromes, such as inappropriate ADH (vasopressin) secretion, should be a suspected diagnosis given this patient’s ED presentation, history of small cell carcinoma of the lung, and hyponatremia on initial laboratory studies.
explanation.educational_objective:
Inappropriate ADH (vasopressin) secretion can be seen as a paraneoplastic syndrome in patients with small cell carcinoma of the lung. In patients presenting with severe hyponatremia, such as those with confusion, stroke-like symptoms,
or seizures, as seen in this patient, prompt correction of hyponatremia is paramount and should be accomplished with intravenous hypertonic saline. To minimize the risk of osmotic demyelination syndrome, the serum sodium should only be corrected to the
point of resolution of acute neurologic symptoms, with slow gradual correction to reach eunatremia in the coming days to weeks. Intravenous administration of 3% saline is the most appropriate

vignette.presentation:
48. AG7-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital because of severe shortness of breath. She has a 15-year history of emphysema. Her written advance directive states that she does not want mechanical ventilation in the event of
respiratory failure. She now states that she has changed her mind and asks the physician to "do everything" for her, including mechanical ventilation if necessary for survival. Her husband states that she never wanted to “live on a
machine." She is oriented to person, place, time, and situation. Her pulse is 110/min, respirations are 28/min and labored, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Examination shows diffuse expiratory wheezing. Inspiratory crackles are
heard over the right upper and lower lung fields. Arterial blood gas analysis on 100% oxygen by face mask shows:
pH 7.19
Peo, 70 mm Hg
Po, 60 mm Hg
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in patient care?

choices.text: Request that the husband decide whether to use mechanical ventilation
Continue oxygen by face mask and administer intravenous morphine for comfort

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Laws regarding advanced directives and the cascade of who becomes a medical decision-maker when a patient is incapacitated vary from state to state. However, generally, legal advanced directives will supersede any outside decision-making
unless expressed directly by the patient. In this case, the patient had an advanced directive where they designated that they did not want to be supported by mechanical ventilation. However, in the setting of an emergency medical condition, she}
has changed her mind, making intubating and beginning mechanical ventilation the most appropriate next step for this patient. It was deemed by the physician through examination that the patient has the capacity (ie, is fully oriented) for
decision-making. Because of this, her current wishes can supersede a written advanced directive, as the advanced directive is designed to be used when the patient is unable to make medical decisions. In all situations, regardless of advanced
directive or family input, if the patient has the capacity to make their own medical decisions, their autonomy should be respected, and their wishes followed at that time.
explanation.educational_objective:
Advanced directives can serve as guidance for physicians during emergency medical situations in which a patient has already addressed their wishes from a health care standpoint. However, patients can revoke or alter
these directives, in real-time, given that they have the capacity to make medical decisions. Assessment of the patient's capacity should be made, and if they are deemed to have the capacity for decision-making, their current wishes should
supersede any written advanced directive. This makes intubation and beginning mechanical ventilation the most appropriate

49. Six hours after undergoing esophagectomy for esophageal cancer, a 52-year-old man's blood pressure increases from 130/86 mm Hg to 180/100 mm Hg. Despite receiving an epidural

infusion of fentanyl, he rates incisional pain as an 8 on a 10-point scale. He is receiving 5% dextrose in 0.45% saline (125 mL/h); including fluids administered intraoperatively, his fluid

balance is +4 L. His postoperative urine output is 50 mL. His pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 18/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 100%. Examination

shows a dry, intact incision site and a patent nasogastric tube that irrigates clear fluid. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is flat, and there is exquisite incisional

tenderness. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.5 g/dL, and hematocrit is 32%. The most appropriate next step in

management of this patient's increased blood pressure is intravenous administration of a medication from which of the following drug classes?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
This patient with elevated blood pressure following a major operation likely has several contributing factors. Postoperative hypertension is a common entity and can be due to several underlying
causes, including pre-existing hypertension, noxious stimuli (pain, bladder overdistension, nausea/vomiting, hypoxia, hypercapnia, shivering, and emergence from medications given
intraoperatively), and hypervolemia. In a patient with postoperative hypertension, a thorough history and physical examination can often be useful in elucidating the cause. This patient likely has
several factors contributing to his hypertension, including severe pain (rated 8 out of 10, exquisite tenderness on examination) and significantly positive fluid balance. His low postoperative urine
output may indicate that he is retaining urine, which could be another source contributing to his discomfort. These factors should all be addressed before making any further decisions regarding
his blood pressure. Appropriate analgesia (eg, narcotics) should be administered, thorough evaluation of his volume status should be done, and a bladder scan should be performed to determine’
if he needs a foley catheter. Resolution of these issues will likely result in significant improvement of his blood pressure.
explanation.educational_objective:
Postoperative hypertension is a common entity and can be due to several underlying causes, including pre-existing hypertension, noxious stimuli (pain, bladder
overdistension, nausea/vomiting, hypoxia, hypercapnia, shivering, and emergence from medications given intraoperatively), and hypervolemia. In a patient with postoperative hypertension, a
thorough history and physical examination can often be useful in elucidating the cause.

vignette.presentation:
50. A 1000-g (2-Ib 3-0z) newborn has no spontaneous breathing following delivery at 34 weeks' gestation. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and he is admitted to the neonatal
intensive care unit. Pregnancy was complicated by marked oligohydramnios. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), and pulse is 160/min. Examination shows flat facies. Breath sounds
are decreased. Heart sounds are normal. There are no abdominal masses. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
B} Gengenitat pneumonia

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Oligohydramnios is a result of minimal fetal urine production and insufficient amniotic fluid. Without the production of amniotic fluid to distribute force evenly over the surface of the developing
fetus, deformities will result. Fetuses with oligohydramnios may exhibit compressed, flattened facial features, limb dysplasia, and pulmonary hypoplasia as a result of inadequate amniotic fluid-
induced lung expansion. This constellation of features is known as the Potter sequence. Causes include premature rupture of the membranes, uteroplacental insufficiency, and congenital
malformations of the fetal genitourinary tract (eg, posterior urethral valves or renal agenesis). Early monitoring for and diagnosis of oligohydramnios is essential to the prevention of developing
Potter sequence. Patients with Potter sequence are generally born with immediate respiratory distress or no spontaneous breathing caused by pulmonary hypoplasia. Many require intubation
and mechanical ventilation as well as admission to the neonatal intensive care unit.
explanation.educational_objective:
Oligohydramnios results from an inadequate amount of amniotic fluid that can cause growth restriction and structural abnormalities of the fetus, including Potter sequence.
Causes include premature rupture of the membranes, uteroplacental insufficiency, and congenital malformations of the fetal genitourinary tract (eg, posterior urethral valves or renal agenesis).
Patients with Potter sequence are generally born with immediate respiratory distress or no spontaneous breathing as a result of pulmonary hypoplasia.

vignette.presentation:
2. A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the onset of severe abdominal pain. During the past 2 months, he has had several 30-minute episodes of mild abdominal
pain after eating fatty foods. There is a family history of anemia. On arrival, the pain is resolving. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. The
spleen tip is palpated 2 cm below the left costal margin. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 10.2 g/dL
Leukocyte count 11,000/mms
Reticulocyte count 12%
Serum
Bilirubin, total 2 mg/dL.
Direct 0.5 mg/dL.
Alkaline phosphatase 50 U/L
AST 55 U/L
ALT 70 U/L
blood smear shows fragmented erythrocytes. Osmotic fragility testing is positive. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows gallstones. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step
in management?

choices.text: Oral ciprofloxacin therapy for 1 week and follow-up examination in 2 weeks
Intravenous antibiotic therapy and endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Hereditary spherocytosis is a disorder of erythrocyte membrane proteins that limits the ability of the cell to conform when passing through narrow capillary beds. This results in early removal of the
erythrocytes by the spleen and resultant extravascular hemolysis, which causes normocytic, hemolytic anemia. Hereditary spherocytosis is the most common disorder of the erythrocyte membrane and
is frequently seen in patients of European descent. Positive family history is generally present. Patients typically present with fatigue, weakness, and pallor, with associated splenomegaly and jaundice
on physical examination. Patients are also prone to cholelithiasis, as seen in this patient, as a result of increased bilirubin gallstones. Laboratory studies generally show anemia and indirect
hyperbilirubinemia along with abnormal results on osmotic fragility testing and eosin-5'-maleimide analysis on flow cytometry. A blood smear shows rounded erythrocytes without central pallor. Splenic
congestion and sequestration are hallmarks of moderate to severe disease. Cholecystectomy is indicated as is splenectomy to reduce the degree of premature erythrocyte consumption (extravascular
hemolysis) and the risk for sequestration crises.
explanation.educational_objective:
Autosomal dominant mutations in ankyrin, spectrin, and band erythrocyte membrane proteins cause hereditary spherocytosis through loss of the normal connection between the
inner membrane skeleton and the outer lipid bilayer. Clinical symptoms include jaundice, splenomegaly, and anemia. Patients are predisposed to bilirubin gallstones as a result of increased
unconjugated bilirubin concentrations. Peripheral smear shows normocytic, normochromic anemia with the presence of spherocytes. Definitive treatment is splenectomy with cholecystectomy also
indicated for this patient.

vignette.presentation: TBD
2. cm dilated and 90% effaced; the vertex is at 0 station. Which of the following is most consistent with these heart tracing findings?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Abealthy fetal heart rate is between 110 and 160 beats per minute (bpm) with 6 to 25 bpm of variability and spontaneous accelerations. Intermittent early and variable decelerations can also occur during the normal process of
labor. Early decelerations are defined as a gradual decrease in the heart rate that nadirs more than 30 seconds after the initiation of heart rate decline. The nadir of heart rate occurs at the same time as the peak of the uterine
contraction. Early decelerations are typically caused by fetal head compression during normal uterine contractions. In contrast, variable decelerations are defined as an abrupt decrease in heart rate of at least 15 bpm that last at
least 15 seconds, but less than 2 minutes. They do not show a specific relation to the uterine contraction tracing. They are caused by umbilical cord compression that results in decreased blood flow to the fetus, an increased
peripheral systemic vascular resistance, and an autonomic response of fetal bradycardia. Short periods of minimal variability may also occur when the fetus is in a sleep cycle. This patient's tracing, with a fetal heart rate of
approximately 150 bpm, spontaneous accelerations, and appropriate variability is most consistent with normal labor.
explanation.educational_objective:
Normal labor is associated with a fetal heart rate tracing that includes a fetal heart rate between 110 and 160 bpm with 6 to 25 bpm of variability, spontaneous accelerations, and intermittent early or
variable decelerations. Early decelerations are caused by fetal head compression, whereas variable decelerations are more commonly caused by umbilical cord compression. Concerning findings on fetal heart rate tracing
include minimal variability, absent accelerations, fetal tachycardia or bradycardia, recurrent variable or late decelerations, and prolonged decelerations. Late decelerations suggest uteroplacental insufficiency with the
constellation of findings being indicative of ongoing fetal hypoxia and acidemia.

vignette.presentation:
4. A3-year-old gil is brought to the office by her mother 2 days afer she suddenly stopped talking. The mother says her daughter has not spoken since returning from a weekend visit at her
father’s house. Previously, she spoke in short sentences. The patient's parents are divorced, and her father has a new girlfriend who has a 4-year-old son. The patient has no history of serious
illness and receives no medications. In the examination room, she looks at books and plays alone quiet. Vital signs are within normal mits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The
Patient looks in the direction of a dropped object that made a loud sound when it hit the ground. She nods or shakes her head in response to questions but does not answer open-ended
questions. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Reassurance that this #9 an age-appropriate phase

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Given this patient's acute signs of regression and acute stress disorder, the physician should ascertain whether a stressful or traumatic event occurred during the patient’s weekend visit with her father
by interviewing the father. Regression refers to returning to a less psychologically developed state. Regression can manifest as tantrums, excessive dependency, excessive demands, loss of
continence, and rarely, mutism (as seen in this patient). Risk factors for regression include underdeveloped coping skills, difficulty with emotion regulation, and stressful or traumatic events. Both adults
and children are vulnerable to regression. Medical hospitalization is a stressor that commonly leads to regression, even in patients without personality disorders. Physical or sexual violence is a major
stressor that can induce regression. Patients who have undergone such an event may demonstrate other symptoms of acute stress disorder, such as changes in arousal and reactivity (eg, being easily
startled as seen in this patient), intrusive thoughts or memories, avoidance of reminders of trauma, and negative moods or thoughts. If child abuse is suspected, child protective services should be
notified, as physicians are mandated reporters. Management may include psychological support, and if the patient experiences severe and persistent symptoms that end up meeting criteria for post-
traumatic stress disorder, antidepressant medication.
explanation.educational_objective:
Patients subjected to stressful or traumatic events commonly regress. Regression can manifest as tantrums, excessive dependency, excessive demands, loss of continence, and
rarely, mutism. As this patient demonstrates the combination of mutism and being easily startled, the physician should screen for the occurrence of a traumatic event by interviewing the patient's father.

vignette.presentation: TBD

6. An 82-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter because she has not had a bowel movement for 2 weeks and has had loss of appetite for 3 days. There is no history of rectal
bleeding or change in stool color or caliber. One year ago, test of the stool for occult blood was negative. Examination shows a large, exophytic, cauliflower-like lesion between the vagina and
rectum. Digital rectal examination shows fecal impaction. A biopsy specimen of the lesion is most likely to show which of the following?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
This elderly patient is presenting with constipation in the setting of a large, exophytic vulvar mass, raising concem for vulvar carcinoma. The most frequent underlying histopathology of vulvar carcinoma
is squamous cell carcinoma, and its incidence is greatest in patients between the ages of 55 and 85 years. Most commonly, it presents with a vulvar nodule, papule, or plaque that may be otherwise
asymptomatic, although the lesion can also be pruritic and friable, leading to ulceration, bleeding, and pain. In rare instances, such as that seen in this patient, squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva can
present as verrucous carcinoma with a large, cauliflower-like growth that can be locally destructive. In addition to the culprit lesion, a physical examination may disclose inguinal lymphadenopathy. Risk
factors include infection with human papillomavirus, smoking, immunosuppression, chronic inflammation (eg, lichen sclerosus), and a history of cervical cancer. Diagnosis is made with a biopsy of the
lesion. Further evaluation should include cervical cancer screening, as concurrent cervical carcinoma is common, and abdominopelvic imaging to determine the extent of the disease. Treatment
includes surgical excision in addition to chemoradiation.
explanation.educational_objective:
Vulvar carcinoma presents most commonly with a lesion of the labia majora in patients aged 55 to 85 years. In most cases, the underlying histopathology is squamous cell
carcinoma. While the lesion is most commonly a papule, nodule, or plaque, squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva can also present with a large, exophytic, cauliflower-like mass that can be locally
destructive. Diagnosis is made with a biopsy of the lesion, and treatment may include surgical excision, chemotherapy, and radiation depending on the extent of the disease.

vignette.presentation:
8. A67-year-old man comes to the physician for a second measurement of his blood pressure. He had a blood pressure of 165/105 mm Hg in his right arm 9 days ago. He takes no
medications. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Today, his blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg in the right arm and 105/65 mm Hg in the left arm. The
remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these blood pressure findings?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Subclavian artery atherosclerosis (SAA) is the most common cause of subclavian artery stenosis and is one form of peripheral arterial disease. Common risk factors include age (typically
age 60 years and above), diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and smoking. Patients classically present with claudication to the affected extremity, pain at rest, and in severe
cases, possible discoloration of distal extremities. One phenomenon, subclavian steal syndrome, presents in a minority of patients with SAA, occurring proximal to the origin of the
ipsilateral vertebral artery. In subclavian steal syndrome, blood flows from the contralateral vertebral artery through the basilar artery, and then in a retrograde fashion down the ipsilateral
vertebral artery and through the affected subclavian artery. Patients with subclavian steal syndrome may present with vertigo, ataxia, nystagmus, and syncope that occur with upper
‘extremity exertion. Physical examination may show a pulse and blood pressure differential between the right and left upper extremities as well as a temperature differential. Duplex
ultrasonography with color flow imaging or CT angiography is used to diagnose SAA. Treatment may involve endovascular techniques such as stenting and angioplasty or open techniques
such as vascular bypass.
explanation.educational_objective:
Subclavian artery atherosclerosis is the most common cause of subclavian artery stenosis. Patients may present with upper extremity claudication, and physical
examination may show a pulse and blood pressure differential between the upper extremities as well as a temperature differential. The diagnosis is confirmed with duplex ultrasonography
or CT angiography.

vignette.presentation:
9. An 18-month-old boy from Afghanistan, who immigrated to the USA with his family 2 days ago, is brought to the emergency department by his mother
because of a 6-hour history of fever and difficulty breathing. The mother says he previously was doing well. Medical history is unremarkable, and he has not
had contact with anyone known to be ill. He receives no medications, and immunization status is unknown. He is sitting on his mother's lap, leaning forward,
and drooling. He appears to be in significant respiratory distress. Vital signs are temperature 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse 120/min, respirations 40/min, and blood
pressure 80/50 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. Physical examination discloses stridor heard without auscultation.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A} Broneheseopy
B} GFsear- ofthe neck
G} IndireetHlaryngeseopy

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Epiglottitis refers to acute infection of the epiglottis. It was commonly caused by Haemophilus influenzae type b prior to widespread pediatric vaccination. Epiglottitis
presents with fever, acute severe pharyngitis, dysphagia, pooling of oral secretions, drooling, and hoarseness. On lateral neck x-rays, it appears as a swollen and
prominent lobule posterior to the tongue and superior to the trachea. Patients typically present in a toxic state and can exhibit rapid respiratory decompensation with
the development of stridor and airway obstruction. First-line therapy is to emergently establish a protected airway through endotracheal intubation. In the setting of
epiglottitis, endotracheal intubation should take place in the operating room under direct visualization with a laryngoscope if the patient is stable enough to permit
transfer out of the emergency department.
explanation.educational_objective:
Epiglottitis is a severe, life-threatening infection and swelling of the epiglottis. A patient with epiglottitis will present with sudden onset of fever,
pharyngitis, dysphagia, pooling of oral secretions, drooling, and hoarseness. Treatment involves emergent airway protection via endotracheal intubation in an
operating room and administration of antibiotics.

vignette.presentation:
10. A57-year-old man with pancreatic cancer is admitted to the hospital because of a 5-day history of moderate epigastric pain that has not responded to oral
hydromorphone therapy. On admission, intravenous hydromorphone is begun. The nurse calls to report that 3 hours ago, she mistakenly administered 5 mg
of hydromorphone instead of the prescribed 0.5 mg. The patient is sleeping comfortably and is easily aroused. His respirations are 12/min, and blood
pressure is 120/78 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Examination shows no other abnormalities. In addition to
reporting the incident to the patient safety committee, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Begin oxygen therapy and transfer the patient to a telemetry unit

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Hydromorphone is an opioid agonist with a short duration of action of 2 to 3 hours. If this patient were to experience opioid toxicity, he would have already shown
signs. Opioid toxicity presents with sedation, respiratory depression, bradycardia, and hypotension. Instead, he is easily aroused and has vital signs within normal
limits. No further medical management is necessary.

vignette.presentation:
44. A16-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a follow-up examination. One month ago, he completed a course of antibiotic therapy for an

ear infection. His mother reports he has a 2-day history of irritability, decreased appetite, and difficulty sleeping. He has been hospitalized for pneumonia

twice during the past 9 months. He appears irritable. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is

92/54 mm Hg. Skin examination shows no abnormalities. Examination of the right ear shows an erythematous, bulging tympanic membrane. Laboratory

studies show a leukocyte count of 16,400/mm3 (74% segmented neutrophils, 17% lymphocytes, and 9% monocytes). Additional serum studies are most likely

to show which of the following?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Decreased B-lymphocyte concentration is a feature of X-linked agammaglobulinemia, caused by defects in the Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene. BTK is necessary
for all stages of B lymphocyte development and proliferation, and a deficiency of this enzyme results in failed B lymphocyte development. As B lymphocytes are
responsible for secreting immunoglobulins once they differentiate into plasma cells, a defect in B lymphocyte maturation leads to a dearth of plasma cells and low
immunoglobulin concentrations of every class, including IgM, IgG, IgE, and IgA. Patients present with recurrent bacterial infections due to impaired humoral immunity,
especially after the first 6 months of life when maternal IgG concentrations wane. Treatment is with intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) concentrates and receipt of all
available immunizations other than live vaccines, which are contraindicated in this population. This patient has evidence of a recurrent bacterial ear infection and
should receive antibiotic therapy in addition to IVIG.
explanation.educational_objective:
Patients with X-linked agammaglobulinemia have mutations in the Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene, which encodes a tyrosine kinase
essential for all stages of B lymphocyte development and proliferation. They present with recurrent bacterial infections, especially after the first 6 months of life, and
low or absent concentrations of all immunoglobulin subclasses. Treatment is with intravenous immunoglobulin concentrates.

vignette.presentation:
12. A27-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of fever and bloody diarrhea; episodes of diarrhea are preceded by abdominal pain. He
has had no weight loss or rash. He takes no medications. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 124/72 mm Hg.
Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness with no rebound or guarding; bowel sounds are increased. Rectal examination shows no abnormalities;
there is no blood or stool in the rectal vault. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
A} Adenovirus
__B) Campylobacter jejuni
DB} Nerwat-virus

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Campylobacter jejuni is a gram-negative, non-spore-forming, oxidase positive, comma-shaped bacterium that is among the most common causes of food poisoning
both in the United States and globally. Infection is transmitted via the fecal-oral route or from contact with infected animals or poorly cooked meats. Infection with C.
Jejuni results in gastroenteritis and presents with fever, crampy abdominal pain, and diarrhea, which may be loose or bloody. Symptoms are typically self-limiting and
resolve over a period of approximately 1 week. Extraintestinal complications of C. jejuni infection include reactive arthritis in patients with HLA-B27 and Guillain-Barré
syndrome. Most patients only need supportive treatment and do not require antibiotics. Antibiotics may be necessary in patients with severe or protracted symptoms,
immunocompromised states, or pregnancy. C. jejuni is the most likely causal organism in this case due to the presence of bloody diarrhea and fever.
explanation.educational_objective:
Campylobacter jejuni is among the most common causes of food poisoning both in the United States and globally. Infection is transmitted via
the fecal-oral route or from contact with infected animals or poorly cooked meats. Infection with C. jejuni results in gastroenteritis and presents with fever, abdominal
pain, and often bloody diarrhea. Extraintestinal complications of C. jejuni infection include reactive arthritis in patients with HLA-B27 and Guillain-Barré syndrome.
Most patients only require supportive care.

vignette.presentation:
13. A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after football practice because of a 45-minute history of bright red blood in his urine. He has no

history of serious illness and receives no medications. His pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 119/73 mm Hg; other vital signs are within normal limits.

Examination shows no ecchymoses, suprapubic tenderness, or abdominal distention; there is moderate tenderness to palpation of the left flank. Which of the

following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Measurement of prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time
Measurement of serum C3 and C4 concentrations
Transfusion of packed red blood cells
Venous Doppler ultrasonography of the lower extremities

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
An abdominal CT scan is most likely to confirm the diagnosis of kidney laceration, hematoma, or other traumatic kidney injury in this patient. Football practice places
the patient at risk for blunt abdominal and flank or retroperitoneal trauma. This patient likely sustained trauma to the flank leading to blunt kidney injury. Given its
retroperitoneal location, isolated kidney injury may not cause abdominal pain, tenderness, or peritonitis on examination. Kidney injury commonly presents with gross
hematuria and is diagnosed with CT scan of the abdomen with intravenous contrast. Minor injuries such as contusions, small lacerations, or small hematomas may
heal without intervention. Larger injuries, injuries with active extravasation, injuries with devascularization or direct large vessel injury, injuries with intraperitoneal
extension, or injuries with urinary obstruction may require surgical or procedural intervention to promote healing or limit morbidity or complications.
explanation.educational_objective:
Blunt traumatic kidney injury commonly presents with gross hematuria and is diagnosed with CT scan of the abdomen with intravenous
contrast.

vignette.presentation: TBD

17. A25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of low-grade fever, sore throat, generalized muscle aches, and fatigue. She also has had moderate neck

pain radiating to her jaw and ears during this period. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is alert and in no distress. Her temperature is 38.2°C

(100.8°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. The thyroid gland is diffusely tender and slightly enlarged. Examination of the head,

ears, eyes, nose, and oropharynx shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show a thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration of 0.5 U/mL and a thyroxine (T,) concentration of

16 uig/dL. A *°1I thyroid scan shows decreased uptake. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
‘Subacute (de Quervain) thyroiditis, also known as subacute granulomatous thyroiditis, is a rare form of thyroiditis characterized by inflammation of the thyroid gland and the presence of
granulomas. Treatment typically includes nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, such as ibuprofen, and corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and pain. This condition is typically preceded
by a viral infection, such as an upper respiratory infection, and is more common in women. Symptoms usually include pain and tenderness in the thyroid area, fever, fatigue, and a swollen
thyroid gland, along with symptoms of hyperthyroidism (eg, anxiety, tremors, weight loss, diarrhea, menstrual irregularities, hot flashes, tachycardia, hypertension, and sweating). Subacute
(de Quervain) thyroiditis is usually self-limiting, and the thyroid gland typically returns to normal function within a few weeks or months. However, in some cases, the patient may
experience temporary or permanent hypothyroidism following the initial period of inflammation and generally transient hyperthyroid symptoms. Subacute (de Quervain) thyroiditis should be
suspected in patients with an enlarged, tender thyroid, history of recent viral illness, and/or increased thyroxine concentrations with decreased thyroid-stimulating hormone concentrations,
as is seen in this patient.
explanation.educational_objective:
Subacute (de Quervain) thyroiditis, also known as subacute granulomatous thyroiditis, is a rare form of thyroiditis that is characterized by inflammation of the thyroid
gland and the presence of granulomas. This condition is often preceded by viral illness. Physical examination will disclose an enlarged, tender thyroid. Laboratory testing will show
decreased thyroid-stimulating hormone and increased thyroxine concentrations. The appropriate treatment includes nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, such as ibuprofen, and
glucocorticoids. Patients should be monitored for the development of hypothyroidism in the period following illness.

vignette.presentation:
18. Apreviously healthy 4-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of fever. She has been feeding poorly and has vomited four times during the past 24
hours. She has not had diarrhea. Immunizations were up-to-date at the age of 2 months. On arrival, she appears somnolent and is irritable. She is at the 50th percentile for length and head
circumference and the 25th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 39.6°C (103.3°F), pulse is 180/min, and respirations are 42/min. Examination shows a full anterior fontanel. The remainder
of the examination shows no abnormalities. A lumbar puncture is performed. A Gram stain of the cerebrospinal fluid is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Bacterial meningitis presents with fever, headache, nuchal rigidity, and altered mental status, typically following a prodrome of upper respiratory tract infection symptoms. In infants, nuchal rigidity is
less common. Physical examination may show a present Kernig or Brudzinski sign, indicative of meningeal irritation, and can also show focal neurologic symptoms or signs of increased intracranial
pressure, which includes a bulging anterior fontanelle in infants. Petechiae may be present. Laboratory studies will show leukocytosis, and coagulation studies can show signs of disseminated
intravascular coagulopathy with thrombocytopenia, decreased fibrinogen, and increased D-dimer, depending on the specific pathogen. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) evaluation is the most appropriate
initial diagnostic step and will show an increased opening pressure, increased white blood cell count with prominent neutrophils, increased protein concentration, and decreased glucose concentration.
Culture of the CSF is used to diagnose the specific bacterial cause and to distinguish between viral and fungal meningitides or alternative diagnoses. Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common
bacterial pathogen beyond the newborn period. It appears on CSF culture as an extracellular, gram-positive (purple on gram staining), lancet-shaped coccus. Treatment involves immediate antibiotic
therapy (eg, vancomycin and a third-generation cephalosporin) and glucocorticoids.
explanation.educational_objective:
Streptococcus pneumoniae, a gram-positive diplococcus, is the most common causative pathogen of bacterial meningitis outside of the newborn period. Bacterial meningitis
presents with fever, altered mental status, headache, meningeal signs such as neck stiffness (though less common in infants), and signs of increased intracranial pressure (eg, bulging anterior
fontanelle). Treatment involves immediate antibiotic therapy (eg, vancomycin and a third-generation cephalosporin) and glucocorticoids.

vignette.presentation:
49. A 63-year-old man who has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) returns to the office for a follow-up visit. His COPD has progressed during the

past 3 years. He smoked cigarettes for 48 years but quit 1 year ago; he continues to have chronic cough, dyspnea on exertion, and episodes of wheezing.

He says he often sleeps in his recliner so that his snoring and coughing will not bother his wife. Current medications include inhaled albuterol, budesonide,

and ipratropium for the past 2 months. He received a pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine, 23-valent, 2 years ago. He is a retired postal worker and is

frustrated because he is no longer able to walk from the car to the poker room at the local community center to play cards with his friends. Today, pulse is

90/min and regular, and blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg. He appears large and has a barrel-shaped chest. Breath sounds are decreased, and scattered

wheezes are heard. No gallops or murmurs are heard on cardiac examination. Leukocyte count is 12,000/mm3 and hemoglobin concentration is 14 g/dL.

After the patient receives nebulized albuterol, pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 86%. Which of the following is the most important

factor in this patient's history and physical examination in determining his prognosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a disease characterized by decreased lung function from a combination of chronic bronchitis and/or emphysema,
resulting in airflow obstruction on expiration. Breath sounds are decreased because of reduced airflow and a prolonged expiratory phase as the pathologically
narrowed airways are further compressed by positive intrathoracic pressure during expiration. Heart sounds may be distant secondary to emphysematous lung
changes (eg, sound is transmitted poorly through air relative to normal lung tissue). Pulmonary abnormalities can be evaluated by pulmonary function testing, which
includes spirometry, full-body plethysmography, single-breath diffusing capacity, arterial blood gas analysis, and pulse oximetry. Spirometry is the most useful in
diagnosing obstructive lung disease, which is defined by a decrease in the ratio of the volume of air forcefully expelled in the first second of expiration to the total
volume of air expelled during the expiratory phase (FEV,/FVC). The severity of obstruction is graded by the amount of FEV, reduction compared to predicted values.
Treatment is focused on smoking cessation and supplemental oxygen to decrease mortality. Symptoms are managed with inhaled short-acting B-adrenergic agonists,
long-acting B-adrenergic agonists, muscarinic antagonists (eg, ipratropium), and glucocorticoids. This patient's continued worsening dyspnea on exertion despite
appropriate medical therapies is the most important factor for determining his prognosis. Prognosis in COPD depends on the functional ability of the lung to serve its
purpose as an organ (ie, gas exchange) in times of rest or activity. In this case, the patient's symptomatic shortness of breath on exertion is an indicator of
progressive organ failure and failure of the organ to respond to an appropriate physiologic demand.
explanation.educational_objective:
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is a lung disease characterized by airflow obstruction. Chronic symptoms are improved with the use of
inhaled long-acting B-adrenergic agonists, muscarinic antagonists, and glucocorticoids. Progressive dyspnea on exertion despite adequate medical therapy indicates
a poor prognosis.

vignette.presentation:
20. A52-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus is admitted to the hospital because of a 3-week history of persistent pain, edema, and erythema of the left foot. She has not sustained trauma to the foot. She has no history of foot ulcers or wounds. Her
medications are insulin and aspirin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the left foot shows diffuse edema, erythema, and warmth; there is no tendemess to palpation. The dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are 2+ bilaterally. Sensation to touch
and pinprick is decreased in a stocking distribution bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Hematocrit 38%
Leukocyte count 10,500/mm: with a normal differential
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 40 mm/h
Serum uric acid 8 mgidL_
Antibiotic therapy is begun. Three days later, examination findings are unchanged. A repeat leukocyte count is within the reference range. Blood cultures obtained before administration of antibiotic therapy show no growth. An x-ray of the left foot is shown. Which of
the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Joint destruction secondary to advanced gouty arthropathy

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Neuropathic arthropathy, also known as Charcot joint, is a progressive degenerative condition that affects the bones, joints, and soft tissues of the foot and ankle. It is caused by damage to the nerves in the feet, leading to decreased sensation and loss of protective
reflexes This results in increased weight bearing and trauma to the affected area. Over time, joint deformities, fractures, and dislocations can occur. Risk factors for neuropathic arthropathy include diabetes, peripheral neuropathy, and neurologic conditions that affect
‘sensation in the feet. It is more common in individuals with a history of trauma or operation of the foot and ankle. Treatment for neuropathic arthropathy typically involves offloading weight from the affected area through use of a cast or a removable boot. Physical therapy
and orthotic devices may be used to support the affected area and prevent further damage. In severe cases, operative repair may be required to correct joint deformities and stabilize the affected area. Complications of neuropathic arthropathy can include chronic pain,
joint deformities, and an increased risk of foot and ankle infections. Amputation may be required in severe cases. Given this patient's history of insulin use, stocking-like sensory loss, and lack of evidence of infection, neuropathic arthropathy is the most likely diagnosis.
explanation.educational_objective:
Neuropathic arthropathy, also known as Charcot joint, is a degenerative condition that affects the bones and joints in the foot and ankle, commonly in patients with diabetes. This condition can lead to pain, swelling, and eventual collapse of joints
resulting in deformity and chronic pain. Complications of neuropathic arthropathy can include chronic pain, joint deformities, and an increased risk of foot and ankle infections.

vignette.presentation:
21. A67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of progressive shortness of breath with walking and climbing stairs. She has had fatigue for the past 2 weeks. She has not had
any other symptoms. She has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Current medications include inhaled albuterol and ipratropium and oral prednisone. She smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for
40 years but stopped 5 years ago. Her pulse is 100/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. Examination
shows pale conjunctivae. Breath sounds are decreased bilaterally. Heart sounds are distant. The spleen tip is palpated 5 cm below the left costal margin. The remainder of the examination shows no
abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 7.2. g/dL
Hematocrit 28%
Leukocyte count 104,000/mm®
‘Segmented neutrophils 69%
Lymphocytes 15%
Metamyelocytes 12%
Myelocytes: 3%
Blasts 1%
Platelet count 93,000/mm?
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
A} Acute myclogenous leukemia

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
This patient most likely has chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), which commonly presents as an incidental laboratory finding in asymptomatic patients. In the chronic phase, patients may also present with
fatigue, night sweats, weight loss, splenomegaly, and fever. CML is defined by the Philadelphia chromosome (translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22). Typical laboratory findings in CML include
hyperleukocytosis, which is present in this case, with an increase in nearly all the myeloid cell lines. Peripheral blood smear will show a diverse array of immature and partially mature cells of the granulocytic
lineage with basophilia. Leukostasis, a condition in which hyperleukocytosis leads to end-organ damage from occlusion of capillaries by malignant, non-distensible cells, is uncommon in CML because malignant
cells are well-differentiated and pliable. This contrasts with conditions such as acute myeloid leukemia and acute lymphocytic leukemia, in which circulating blasts, which are large and not particularly pliable,
easily lodge in capillaries to cause pulmonary and neurologic complications. Treatment of CML is primarily with tyrosine kinase inhibitors such as imatinib or dasatinib and routine laboratory monitoring. Such
medications are effective and often result in complete molecular response (ie, remission) within several months of initiation.
explanation.educational_objective:
Chronic myelogenous leukemia is a common myeloproliferative disorder encountered in older adults, caused by the reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22 known as the
Philadelphia chromosome. In the chronic phase, patients present with nonspecific symptoms and laboratory studies showing proliferation of myeloid cell lines and their precursors.

vignette.presentation:
23. A27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 18 weeks’ gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal visit. Her 5-year-old son recently received the diagnosis of

erythema infectiosum (fifth disease). Examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Human parvovirus B19 (erythema infectiosum), in the context of an acquired infection while pregnant, is typically a mild viral syndrome that may include a rash, fever, chills, headache,
myalgias, arthralgias, nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramping, diarrhea, or mild respiratory symptoms. The rash seen in adult human parvovirus B19 infection is variable in distribution,
less likely to demonstrate the characteristic red cheek appearance seen in children, and may not be present at all. It is generally self-resolving and seldom carries a significant burden of
morbidity in otherwise healthy people. There may be consequences of maternal human parvovirus B19 infections for the developing fetus, however, especially if the infection is acquired
in the second or third trimester. Human parvovirus B19 has a tropism for bone marrow and infects erythroid progenitor cells, which can cause fetal anemia. Fetal anemia may present as
fetal tachycardia, high-output heart failure, hydrops fetalis, and death. Parvovirus is also a potential cause of fetal myocarditis. This pregnant patient has been exposed to parvovirus via
her 5-year-old son, and because symptoms are mild and may go unnoticed, determining whether she has been infected through measurement of serum-specific IgG and IgM
concentrations is the most appropriate next step in management. Increased concentration of IgG in the absence of IgM indicates a previous infection, while increased concentrations of
both indicate a current or recent infection. Determining whether or not this patient has been infected will help guide further management of her pregnancy, including the need for additional
testing or sonography.
explanation.educational_objective:
Human parvovirus B19 presents in an adult as a mild viral syndrome that may include a rash, fever, chills, headache, myalgias, arthralgias, nausea, vomiting,
abdominal cramping, diarrhea, or mild respiratory symptoms. In pregnant patients, it can cause hydrops fetalis of the fetus secondary to fetal anemia and high-output cardiac failure,
especially when the infection occurs in the second or third trimester. Confirmation of the diagnosis can be made with measurement of serum-specific IgG and IgM concentrations.
Increased concentration of IgG in the absence of IgM indicates a

vignette.presentation:
24. A17-year-old girl comes to the office for contraceptive counseling. She requests a specific brand-name oral contraceptive because she heard

from her friends that it works well and also helps control acne. The physician informs her that this particular drug has a higher co-payment and

there are similar oral contraceptives that would provide the same benefits. The patient refuses any other oral contraceptive, and she says that

she has a good job and can afford the more expensive one. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?

choices.text: Discuss other medications to treat the patient's acne
Offer the patient a schedule of depot medroxyprogesterone acetate injections instead
Tell the patient not to believe drug company advertisements

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
This physician is facing a conflict between the ethical principles of autonomy and beneficence. The physician believes it would be beneficial to this patient
to use an oral contraceptive that is both effective and cost-effective as opposed to one that is effective but not cost-effective. However, the principle of
autonomy posits that capacitated patients have the right to make their own decisions regarding their health care, even if the physician disagrees with the
decision. As such, the physician should prescribe the oral contraceptive that the patient requested. The exception to this ethical guideline is when the
patient asks for an intervention that is likely to directly harm their health or bodily integrity without providing significant benefit (eg, prescribing a
benzodiazepine for a patient with an active substance use disorder, performing a medically unnecessary surgery). In the case of this exception, the
physician may invoke their duty to “do no harm,” or nonmaleficence, and decline the patient's request.
explanation.educational_objective:
Patients have an ethical right to make autonomous health decisions, even if the physician disagrees with the decision. The
exception to this guideline is when the patient asks for an intervention that is likely to directly harm their health without providing significant benefit. In the
case of this exception, the physician may invoke their duty to “do no harm,” or nonmaleficence, and decline the patient's request.

26. A32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 24-hour history of increasingly severe lower abdominal pain. She has been unable to

eat anything for 12 hours because of nausea. She has been taking sulfasalazine for ulcerative colitis for 6 months. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F).

Examination shows a distended, tympanitic abdomen. There is tenderness to palpation of the lower quadrants. Bowel sounds are decreased. An x-ray of the

abdomen shows a dilated colon and gas in the bowel wall. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Observation with the patient receiving nothing orally

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Ulcerative colitis is a type of inflammatory bowel disease that results in inflammation and ulceration of the colonic mucosa and submucosa, typically beginning in the rectum
and advancing proximally in a continuous distribution. Symptoms include chronic abdominal pain, weight loss, bloody diarrhea, abdominal bloating, and tenesmus. Imaging
typically shows loss of haustral markings. Diagnosis of ulcerative colitis is confirmed by colonoscopy and biopsy, which shows characteristic crypt abscesses. Potential
complications of ulcerative colitis are fulminant colitis, toxic megacolon, and perforation. This patient likely has toxic megacolon, which is a constellation of fever, tachycardia,
hypotension, leukocytosis, enlarged and dilated bowel, and impaired colonic motility. Treatment of ulcerative colitis includes immunomodulators, biologics, and corticosteroids.
In severe cases, an exploratory laparotomy and partial or total colectomy may be required, especially in cases of toxic megacolon.
explanation.educational_objective:
Toxic megacolon can be a severe complication of ulcerative colitis. It typically presents with fever, tachycardia, hypotension, enlarged and dilated
bowel, and impaired colonic motility. Exploratory laparotomy and partial or total colectomy may be required in severe cases.

vignette.presentation: TBD

27. A36-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 2-month history of a mildly painful rash around her mouth and vagina, decreased sense of taste, and hair
loss. Six months ago, she underwent uncomplicated Roux-en-Y gastric bypass because of obesity. Since that time, she has had a 27-kg (60-Ib) weight loss. She has
type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Her medications are metformin and amlodipine. She takes a multivitamin inconsistently. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and
weighs 95 kg (210 Ib); BMI is 37 kg/m?, Her pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Examination shows an erythematous, scaling rash in the perioral
and perianal areas. There is diffuse thinning of the hair over the scalp. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is obese, and there is
diffuse, mild tenderness to palpation. Bowel sounds are normal. Supplementation with which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
This patient’s symptoms of dermatitis, alopecia, and taste disturbance are suggestive of zinc deficiency. Zinc is an important cofactor for numerous metalloenzymes
throughout the body. Acquired zinc deficiency is rare but may occur in the setting of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, as in this case. Zinc deficiency typically presents with signs
and symptoms including disturbances of taste and smell (hyposmia or hypogeusia), neuropsychiatric disturbances, dermatitis, brittle hair, alopecia, paronychia, delayed
wound healing, and immune dysfunction. The dermatitis is often scaly and erythematous and may present with angular cheilitis or anogenital lesions. The diagnosis is
confirmed with serum testing of zinc concentration. Serum testing is also useful for excluding other vitamin deficiencies that are frequently concomitant in the setting of gastric
bypass (particularly vitamin B, [thiamine], vitamin B42 [cobalamin], vitamin A, and iron). Treatment is with oral zinc supplementation.
explanation.educational_objective:
Zinc deficiency presents with disturbances of taste and smell, neuropsychiatric disturbances, dermatitis, brittle hair, alopecia, paronychia, delayed
wound healing, and immune dysfunction. Zinc deficiency may occur as a result of intestinal malabsorption, such as following Roux-en-Y gastric bypass. The diagnosis is
confirmed with serum testing of zinc concentration. Treatment is with oral zinc supplementation.

vignette.presentation:
29. A42-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the sudden onset of left-sided weakness and a moderate headache while exercising

at the gym. She reports that the weakness occurred almost immediately after the sudden onset of pain in her right jaw that radiated to the right temple. She has no

history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is awake and alert. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg.

Examination shows left homonymous hemianopia. The right pupil is 2 mm, and the left is 4 mm. Both pupils are reactive to light. There is partial ptosis of the right

‘eye and drooping of the left lower aspect of the face. Muscle strength is 5/5 in the right extremities and 4/5 in the left extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ in the

right extremities and 3+ in the left extremities. Babinski sign is absent on the right and present on the left. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
This patient with sudden-onset jaw pain, headache, and neurologic deficits that began while exercising has a presentation consistent with carotid artery dissection. Carotid
artery dissection is a common cause of stroke in patients in their fourth to fifth decades and may be associated with an underlying connective tissue disorder, such as
fibromuscular dysplasia or Ehlers Danlos syndrome. Carotid artery dissection is usually precipitated by a minor traumatic or mechanical event (eg, exercise, cervical
manipulation, coughing, weightlifting). This trauma leads to hematoma formation between arterial wall layers, followed by dissection through the layers, and luminal stenosis
or occlusion, which ultimately produces the neurologic deficits caused by impaired cerebral perfusion. Patients frequently present with ipsilateral head, neck, or face pain,
thought to be the result of nociceptor activation secondary to vascular distention. Other common symptoms include Horner syndrome, cranial neuropathies, and symptoms
consistent with ischemia to the anterior or middle cerebral artery distribution. Diagnosis is made with CT or MR angiography. Treatment is like that of patients with ischemic.
stroke and may include administration of antiplatelet agents, alteplase, mechanical thrombectomy, and/or endovascular stenting.
explanation.educational_objective:
Carotid artery dissection is usually precipitated by a minor traumatic or mechanical event, such as exercise or vigorous coughing. Patients may present
with headache, jaw, or face pain, with associated focal neurologic deficits. Diagnosis is made with CT or MR angiography.

30. Apreviously healthy 18-year-old primigravid woman at 22 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of a genital lesion for 2 days. She is sexually active with

multiple partners, but she has no history of sexually transmitted diseases. Examination shows a 1.5-cm, painless, superficial ulcer on the left labium majus. There is

nontender, firm inguinal lymphadenopathy. Serologic testing 8 weeks ago was negative for syphilis, Neisseria gonorrhoeae, and Chlamydia trachomatis. Which of

the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Avariety of sexually transmitted infections may cause the formation of a nontender genital ulcer. These include syphilitic chancre caused by Treponema pallidum,
lymphogranuloma venereum caused by Chlamydia trachomatis subtypes L1, L2, and L3, and granuloma inguinale caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. In contrast, genital
herpes and chancroid, caused by herpesvirus 2 and Haemophilus ducreyi, respectively, are both characterized by painful genital ulcers. Primary syphilis causes a shallow
chancre with a clean base that may be associated with inguinal lymphadenopathy, which makes it the most likely diagnosis in this patient with multiple sexual partners.
Untreated syphilis develops in multiple stages with varying symptoms, including primary with a painless chancre as described, secondary with fever, lymphadenopathy, and
condylomata lata, and tertiary with neurosyphilis, tabes dorsalis, aortitis, and gummas. Serologic testing for syphilis is first performed with a nontreponemal test, such as a
venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test or rapid plasma reagin (RPR). During the early phases of primary syphilis, VDRL test and RPR may be negative, as in this
case. If there is ongoing clinical concem, the RPR should be repeated. These tests are typically performed as a screening test, and if positive, should be followed up with a
treponemal test, such as the fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption (FTA-ABS) test. Infection in pregnant patients can lead to neonatal abnormalities, such as
hepatomegaly, rhinitis, maculopapular rash, epitrochlear lymphadenopathy, and chorioretinitis, and thus, pregnant patients should be treated for syphilis expeditiously.
Treatment consists of benzathine penicillin G, making this the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient.
explanation.educational_objective:
Nontender genital ulcers may be caused by Treponema pallidum (primary syphilitic chancre), Chlamydia trachomatis subtypes L1, L2, and L3
(lymphogranuloma venereum), and Klebsiella granulomatis (granuloma inguinale). A primary syphilitic chancre is a shallow ulcer with a clean base that may be associated
with inguinal lymphadenopathy. Serologic testing may be negative early in the course of the infection. Treatment consists of benzathine penicillin G, which should be
administered expeditiously in pregnant patients given the risk for adverse outcomes in the neonate.
